American chestnuts used to be plentiful. But a blight imported from Asia in the late 1800s decimated the species almost out of existence. Now scientists say they‚Äôve found a way to resurrect the chestnut by giving it a gene that shields it from the blight‚Äôs poison. It‚Äôd be the first use of genetic engineering for ecological restoration -- and probably not the last. Across the country, forests face growing threats from invasive pests, diseases and climate change. But genetic engineering raises a host of difficult questions, like: how much humans should intervene in nature in the name of conservation.
üì∏: @allisonzaucha for the L.A. Times

Fans gathered around Los Angeles today to pay respects on the tenth anniversary of #MichaelJackson's death. Flowers were placed on his Hollywood Walk of Fame star and fans also gathered at the Holly Terrace Grand Mausoleum where Jackson is buried. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

When Tom Carruth was 5, he sat on his stoop, entranced by the pale purple rose, ‚ÄúSterling Silver.‚Äù Now, at 67, he‚Äôs spent a lifetime concocting roses himself and is an 11-time winner of the top prize in rose breeding. One of his newest creations is the ‚ÄúHuntington‚Äôs 100th,‚Äù a multicolor, fragrant rose celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens. The hype around the rose is growing like weeds. üì∏: Mel Melcon

Mourners, including law enforcement officers from across the state, said their final goodbye to Joseph Gilbert Solano on Monday, two weeks after the Los Angeles County Sheriff‚Äôs deputy was shot while standing in line in civilian clothing at a Jack in the Box in Alhambra. He died two days later. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre missing one, but we gained one from above,‚Äù said Sheriff Alex Villanueva. üì∏: @alseib

For Santa Anita‚Äôs low-paid workers, horse deaths bring pain and fear about the future. Roughly 1,500 backstretch workers labor behind the scenes as grooms, trainers, exercise riders and stable cleaners. There have been 30 horse deaths at the track since the start of the racing season, Dec. 26, and some authorities are calling to suspend racing at the track. The workers‚Äô biggest fear is that the track will be shut down permanently amid the controversy, threatening their livelihood. üì∏: @kentnish

Wondering what life on Mars might look like? You can find out in the Utah desert, where the Mars Desert Research Station has acted as a reliable stand-in for an actual base on Mars since 2001. With NASA‚Äôs plan to land humans on Mars by 2033 and the promise of commercial space travel, interest in the station has soared. Engineers, physicians, geologists, and others come to the station to test ideas related to living on Mars. üì∏: @bvanderbrug

Motivated by the death of rap star Nipsey Hussle, Los Angeles-area gangs are engaging in the most ambitious effort to end violence since the 1992 riots. Leaders of the peace movement say the outpouring of grief after Hussle‚Äôs March 31 death has made it easier to convince others that the cycle of violence needs to stop. üì∑: @genaro4707

Built on testosterone, flop sweat and gigantic globs of flame, Irwindale Speedway offers family entertainment at a fair price. ‚ÄúAt Irwindale Speedway, the living is easy, the spectacle ‚Ä¶ well, you decide,‚Äù writes columnist Chris Erskine. ‚ÄúFelonious? Fiery? Silly? Astonishing?‚Äù Pictured above is a stunt driver successfully spinning a Ford over eight cars in one of the night's early jumps. The flames were set intentionally to enhance the spectacle. üì∏: Gina Ferazzi

Once a sleepy family neighborhood, Highland Park has rocketed into a hipster haven ‚Äî but there's still much that's authentic. Highland Park is no less culturally and artistically interesting than before the hipsters moved in, @makekeeee writes.
üì∏: @ginaferazzi

It‚Äôs always ‚ÄúTake Your Dog To Work Day‚Äù at Amazon in Seattle, where more than 7,000 dogs are registered to come to work. That amounts to a dog-person ratio of 1:7 at the mothership. When their owners have meetings, dogs can pop into a doggy day-care spot for a shampoo, blow dry and ‚Äúnail pawlish.‚Äù They can also play on a 17th-floor deck created just for them, with ornamental fire hydrants and artificial grass. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure Amazon dogs have the best life,‚Äù says Lauren Lee, an Amazon Home senior product manager. üì∏: @duceyphoto

#TBT: A brawl marred the Father‚Äôs Day 1977 @Dodgers-@Cubs baseball game. These three photos by staff photographer Steve Fontanini appeared in the June 20, 1977, Los Angeles Times. üì∏: Steve Fontanini

In response to the college admissions scandal, the University of California released sweeping reforms to better police fraudulent admissions. Though UC was not the only school system implicated in the scandal, UC president Janet Napolitano, above, plans to implement changes, such as reviewing links between donors and applicants, having a higher level of scrutiny for special talent admits like athletes and verifying students‚Äô claims on applications more strictly. üì∏: @genaro4707

Moviegoers will still hear Don Rickles‚Äô voice in ‚ÄúToy Story 4‚Äù two years after his death. Rickles, who is the voice behind Mr. Potato Head, died in April 2017 at the age of 90 but wanted his name to be kept alive. Thanks to a painstaking archival process, quotes like ‚ÄúYou got to be kidding me‚Äù and ‚ÄúI knew it‚Äù have been resurrected for the film. üì∏: @annecusack

Banh Cuon refers to steamed rice sheets, ‚Äúwhich may be served as is, laid out flat with toppings such as fried shallot and fresh herbs, or they may be filled and rolled,‚Äù Andrea Nguyen writes. Pictured here is Banh Cuon Luu Luyen, a Garden Grove restaurant that offers a peek at the rice sheets being made in the kitchen. üì∏: @mariahtauger

A swarm of 1,000 earthquakes hit Southern California in the last three weeks ‚Äî how nervous should we be? ‚ÄúAny time you have an increase in the number of small earthquakes, you‚Äôre likely to increase the likelihood of a slightly larger earthquake happening,‚Äù said U.S. Geological Survey research geophysicist Andrea Llenos. Read our latest from @ronlin2 for more. Pictured here is damage from the magnitude 6.7 Northridge Earthquake in Jan. 1994. üì∏: Michael Edwards and Los Angeles Times Graphics

Who gets the biggest chunk of the billions taken in by the lottery each year? Lottery winners. Richard Litton, above, holds $3,000 to purchase 1,500 Powerball tickets in Hawthorne. Revenue from lottery tickets also goes to K-12 schools, but it was never intended to provide major funding. The record $1.7 billion sent to schools last year only covered about 1.5% of the state‚Äôs total education budget. üì∏: @alseib

Los Angeles school leaders voted Tuesday to end a policy of randomly searching students with metal detectors during the school day, a decades-old practice that a coalition of students and advocates has been trying to eliminate for years. More than 100 student activists and community advocates swarmed the L.A. Unified school board meeting to speak against the policy. The resolution calls for the superintendent to end the searches by July 2020, and to come up with an alternative policy that would avoid an increased police presence at schools. üì∏: @alschaben

After an emotional, and at times contentious, City Council meeting June 17, West Hollywood‚Äôs first four marijuana dispensaries can continue selling recreational cannabis after they originally lost their bids for licenses. Nearly 100 groups applied for eight licenses, and when the results were announced in December, none of the four dispensaries whose owners say they effectively built the city‚Äôs weed industry ended up with the right to sell. But with their advocacy, that changed. üì∏: Ana Venegas

After the devastation of the Camp fire in Paradise, Shane Grammer found a way to bring beauty to the city. He has painted more than a dozen murals, adorning rusted cars and crumbling concrete walls. The inspiration for the murals came from the biblical book Song of Solomon. ‚ÄúHow beautiful you are, my darling!‚Äù the king declares to his beloved in the verse. ‚ÄúOh, how beautiful! Your eyes are doves.‚Äù üì∏: Carolyn Cole

It was a typical Friday night at Costco in Corona. Customers, including an off-duty Los Angeles police officer, 32-year-old Kenneth French and his parents, waited in line for food samples. It was in this sample line that a lethal confrontation began. According to an attorney, the officer was knocked to the ground by a large man later identified as French. The officer then fired his gun several times. French‚Äôs injuries were fatal and his parents were also shot and taken to the hospital in critical condition. Los Angeles investigators are assessing whether the officer violated any department policies in the shooting. üì∏: Patrick Smith

Arnulfo Gonzalez is the Da Vinci of dirt. His box truck is his canvas, and the filth caked into it, his paint. The Mexican immigrant, who is now a trucker, once had ambitions to become an artist. Now, he offers a new ‚Äúpainting‚Äù each week to commuters across Southern California. ‚ÄúI want to graduate to a wall,‚Äù Gonzalez said. But for now, grime is like an ink that never runs dry. üì∏: @pixtakerirfan

For the first time in history, Guatemalan citizens living in the United States could vote in their country‚Äôs elections from afar. After traveling six hours by bus from Oakland with his wife and children, Mynor Hernandez arrived in Los Angeles, one of four U.S. areas where Guatemalans were able to cast absentee ballots Sunday. Hernandez lifted his red-stained finger ‚Äî marked with ink after he handed in his ballot ‚Äî to applause. üì∏: @jlcvisuals

For nearly two decades, Washington Governor Jay Inslee has sounded warnings about climate change, pictured here visiting a trailer park razed by the Woolsey fire in California. Now the Washington governor is basing his presidential campaign on it, releasing one of the most comprehensive climate proposals out of the slate of Democratic presidential hopefuls. The question now: will voters listen? üì∏: Mel Melcon

Plant a native; help save Los Angeles. That‚Äôs Cassy and Kirk Aoyagi‚Äôs mission. They‚Äôre not alone. All over Southern California, gardeners are removing their turf lawns and replacing them with indigenous plantings, prompted by turf removal rebates, the opportunity to combat climate change and, as Kirk says, ‚Äújust doing the right thing.‚Äù üì∏: @katiefalkenberg

In the skating world, little Sky Brown is a very big deal ‚Äî a girl who by the time she is 12 might equal the record as the youngest athlete to compete in a Summer #Olympics. Of course, that‚Äôs 14 months down the road. Right now, @skybrown is 10, a child prodigy who has an endorsement deal with @Nike, close to 400,000 followers on @Instagram and more than 6 million views on a @youtube channel she shares with her little brother, @oceanbrown. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a phenom,‚Äù said legendary skater @christianhosoi, who has become a mentor. ‚ÄúShe was good at 7. So for her to be now developing at 10, and for difficult tricks that she's doing in the bowl and then connecting them together, it's really extraordinary.‚Äù üì∏: @alschaben

A week to the day after he turned 85, Saul Isler graduated from Santa Monica College. Isler, an author of three short story collections, three novels and a treatise on acrostic puzzles, might have retired around the time the other grads were born, had he been the retiring sort. The first day of his writing class, he saw all of the students on their phones. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòWhoa everybody, my name is Saul and I want to know your names and why is nobody talking?‚Äô‚Äù Isler said. ‚ÄúAnd that began a relationship.‚Äù Visit the link in our bio to read more. üì∏: @genaro4707

The smell of pot overwhelms wine tasting rooms downwind. Vast rows of marijuana hoop houses stand out on the pastoral landscape. Acres of bell peppers have become acres of cannabis. Wine country, make way for weed country‚Äîat least in Santa Barbara County. üì∏: @alseib

As the 2020 census nears, concerns about a possible undercount of Native Americans are gaining traction on the Navajo Nation reservation and across the country. Nearly 600,000 Native Americans live on tribal reservations. Most are remote and all are home to a longstanding distrust of the U.S. government. In the 2010 count, 1 in every 7 Native Americans living on a reservation was missed, according to an audit by the U.S. Census Bureau. With seats in Congress and statehouses determined by population, political power and economic allocations are at stake. Local tribal council leader Jay DeGroat believes that relying on the federal government to take the lead in locating and enumerating everyone is a mistake. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs on us,‚Äù he says. üì∏: @bvanderbrug

L.A. County Sheriff‚Äôs Deputy Joseph Solano has died after he was shot in a random attack. The 50-year-old had been in grave condition since Monday night, when investigators say a Utah man shot him in the head for no apparent reason. ‚ÄúHe confronted a threat not knowing what it was, and in a split second, he lost his life, and that‚Äôs what it is in law enforcement,‚Äù L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said during a news conference. A procession for Solano was held Wednesday night along Marengo Street from Los Angeles County + USC Medical Center to the Coroner's Office. üì∏: @kentnish

Food critic Lucas Kwan Peterson has done the investigation we‚Äôve all been waiting for: ‚Äúthe unassailable, infallibly factual and 100% correct L.A. Times Candy Bar Power Rankings.‚Äù And 30 candy bars later, the results are in. In first place? Take 5, largely because of the pretzel, @staletwizzlers said. Hershey‚Äôs Milk Chocolate took up the rear, with an ‚Äúacrid, waxy, almost rancid-tasting‚Äù flavor that‚Äôs ‚Äúbarely chocolate.‚Äù See the full list of winners online and let us know what you think below. üì∏: @kentnish

Words like "closure‚Äù and ‚Äúforgiveness‚Äù simply aren‚Äôt in Kim Goldman's lexicon. Goldman, on the far right in the first photo, is still trying to make O.J. Simpson pay for the death of her brother, Ron Goldman, 25 years later. Ron and Nicole Brown Simpson, O.J. Simpson‚Äôs ex-wife, were murdered in Nicole‚Äôs townhouse in June 1994. The iconic white Bronco police chase followed a few days later when Simpson failed to turn himself in to authorities. In 1995, O.J. Simpson was found not guilty. üì∏: Los Angeles Times archives

Looking to get away? This Greek island is offering housing, land and 500 euro a month to four families that are moving there. One potential downfall is its history as an island of silence, with the current population listed at just 20. üì∏: Maria Petrakis

What do you think of when you hear the word ‚Äúwitch‚Äù? Pointy black hats? The Salem witch trials? The free-spirited members of the pagan religion Wicca? Today‚Äôs working witches, whose prominence is growing thanks to social media, primarily see themselves as healers. They help clients who are struggling to cope with life‚Äôs hurdles ‚Äî heartache, aging, misogyny, work stress ‚Äî and who find that more culturally accepted remedies, such as therapy and meditation, aren‚Äôt enough. There‚Äôs no official list of job duties for witches, no state licensing board that notes educational or training requirements. But interest in witchcraft is growing once again ‚Äî including in Los Angeles‚Äô own local witches. üì∏: @myung_chun

StayTony Los Angeles in Hollywood is a recent addition to the corporate housing market, featuring furnished, refurbished apartments for a minimum stay of 31 days and a minimum price of $3,300 a month. Housing advocates argue that corporate housing buildings function similarly to hotels and take away apartment space from residents, but owner Tony Diamond disagrees. Meanwhile, StayTony is expanding in Hollywood and, potentially, to Venice. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

The La Brea Tar Pits, formed some 38,000 years ago and excavated in 1913, are getting a fresh new look. Or, at least, the land surrounding the pits is being rethought. On Thursday, officials from the @nhmla, which manages the site, announced the selection of three architectural firms that will develop separate proposals for a new master plan for the 12-acre site, which includes the @thelabreatarpits, the George C. Page Museum and surrounding parkland. Any new plan is intended to consider the entirety of the site ‚Äî the land north and east of the neighboring @lacma ‚Äî and make recommendations for maintenance and redesign. üì∏: @stuartpalley

After coming out last month, Nathan Ivie became the first openly gay Republican to ever hold elected office in Utah. After attempting suicide at 22, Ivie went on to marry, have kids, breed horses for a living and get into politics, all the while keeping his sexuality to himself. A horse was the first living thing he came out to. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt judge you,‚Äù he says. Unsurprisingly, Ivie‚Äôs coming out has gotten some criticism in Utah. But he‚Äôs also received overwhelming support from all over the state and the country with letters and emails lauding his courage. üì∏: @bvanderbrug

Over a half-century, the Los Angeles pride parade has helped chronicle the LGBTQ community in Southern California. Once each decade‚Äîincluding today‚Äîthe parade commemorates the Stonewall uprising. Here is a look back at the event, starting from the first parade in 1970, through the pages of The Times. üì∑: Los Angeles Times staff

The last abortion clinic in #Missouri is now under siege. Dr. David Eisenberg works at the St. Louis @plannedparenthood. Last week, days after the state‚Äôs governor signed a law banning abortions after eight weeks of pregnancy, state officials moved to shut down the clinic, which would make Missouri the first state without a place for women to legally have the procedure since 1974, the year after the U.S. Supreme Court guaranteed the right to the procedure. If the clinic closes, many of the Missouri Planned Parenthood patients will move across the river to the Illinois clinic run by Dr. Eisenberg‚Äôs wife, Dr. Erin King. üì∏: @whitneycphoto

Jennifer Lopez is turning 50 in July and she‚Äôs going on tour to celebrate. At the It‚Äôs My Party Tour, @jlo spins, slides, shimmies and twerks ‚Äî flouting the industry‚Äôs ageist streak through it all. ‚ÄúSome of the people I work with are like, ‚ÄòWhy are you doing this? Now everybody‚Äôs out there saying you‚Äôre 50.‚Äô ‚Äù Lopez said. ‚ÄúI am 50. But I feel like I‚Äôm 28.‚Äù Photographer Kent Nishimura captured her show at a rehearsal last month. üì∏: @kentnish

On one side of the road, homeless tents line the sidewalk. Across the street, the sidewalk is clear. The only difference lies in the invisible boundary line separating Culver City from Los Angeles City. Pictured here is Linda Miranda, 62, who has been living under the overpass for months. Miranda said police prohibit her from even walking into Culver City and regularly instruct homeless people to move their belongings to the L.A. side of the street at the 405 Freeway overpass. L.A. could take Culver City and others to court over the right of homeless to sleep on their streets. üì∏: @francineorr

At the Gu√©delon medieval construction site in central France, workers are recreating a 13th century castle from scratch with the methods and materials in use in the Middle Ages. The traditional skills being rediscovered at the site are in demand for the reconstruction of the Notre Dame cathedral, ravaged by fire in April. Even before the Notre Dame fire, there were plans to open an artisan trade school offering a fully-recognized diploma in historical renovation. Post inferno, it may be even more necessary. üì∏: @kiran_ridley

In Palm Springs, architects, designers and craftsmen are working to restore Bob Hope's legendary estate. While architect John Lautner envisioned a residence that blended in with the surrounding rocky landscape, Bob and Dolores Hope had other ideas. When the house was completed in 1980, Lautner walked away dismayed. The desert residence was considered as a footnote, rather than a highlight, in a distinguished career. Until now. Thanks to the deep pockets of venture capitalist Ron Burkle, the house is being remade to reflect the architect‚Äôs original vision. üì∏: @myung_chun

Wendy Matney has a form of epilepsy that causes frequent, sometimes violent, seizures. She has been to the hospital enough to know a trip means thousands of dollars in bills under the family‚Äôs high-deductible health plan. And she and her husband ‚Äî struggling with more than $20,000 in medical debt ‚Äî can afford no more. As drug prices skyrocket and deductibles increase, sick Americans now pay thousands of dollars every year to get care they need. Those with chronic conditions are hit even harder. üì∏: @jessicatezak

On June 6, 1944, news of the Allied invasion of France arrived in Los Angeles. Residents responded with prayer and a renewed sense of purpose. The next day, the Los Angeles Times reported, ‚ÄúIn cathedrals, in temples, in tiny churches and in homes of rich and poor, the city prayed so that its sons and daughters in the armed forces may safely and speedily crush the dictatorial foes of liberty.‚Äù At a local plant, the general sentiment reportedly was, ‚ÄúThis is it. Let‚Äôs get it over with.‚Äù Check out some photos of the announcement from our archives, 75 years after news hit the city. üì∏: @latimesphoto Archive

Ellan Levitsky loved her service as an Army nurse in Normandy just after the D-Day landings. Now, the 99-year-old is back to France to mark the 75th anniversary of D-Day. In Sainte-Mere-Eglise, Ellan Levitsky and her sister, who also served as a nurse, are held in great esteem by locals grateful for their war work.  In 2012, they were awarded the Legion d‚ÄôHonneur, France‚Äôs highest honor. ‚ÄúIn the U.S. nobody even looks at my medal. Here they come over and shake my hand and say thank you for being in Normandy,‚Äù she says. üì∏: @kiran_ridley

California‚Äôs Central Valley used to be just a pass-through for presidential candidates. Now, it‚Äôs become a destination. In the San Joaquin Valley, about 1 in 5 live below the poverty line. Six of its eight counties are majority Latino. During a town hall in Fresno, Pete Buttiegieg made a point of acknowledging the valley‚Äôs struggles with poverty and inequality, equating them to those of his city of South Bend, which has been ravaged by decades of industrial decline. üì∏: @kentnish

Late-night cricket matches are a long-standing tradition in Pakistan during Ramadan, when Muslims abstain from eating and drinking during the day. On this Saturday in May in West Covina, scores of Muslims, both immigrant and U.S.-born, combined traditions from the motherland with the American culture that they‚Äôve come to cherish. Doing so transformed the stadium into a space that helped revive their faith and recall childhood memories from Pakistan while allowing them to embrace their identities as Americans. üì∏: Irfan Khan

A young Lyndon B. Johnson is believed to have danced at Twin Sisters Dance Hall in Blanco, Texas. In 140 years, the hall has never stopped hosting dances. But it‚Äôs come close. Dance halls are a Texas tradition. The state once filled about 1,000 of them. Now there are about 400. They‚Äôre a piece of living history. Now, many across the state are trying to save the remaining halls. Builders‚Äô descendents are restoring the halls; admirers are organizing statewide tours. üì∏: @katiefalkenberg

Facing strong opposition from California cities, a state lawmaker shelved a bill that would have required municipalities to lift bans on cannabis stores if their voters supported Proposition 64, which legalized the state‚Äôs pot market. The measure would have required one licensed cannabis store for every six restaurants and bars with liquor licenses, or one for every 15,000 residents, whichever provides fewer pot shops. If the bill had passed, according to the study, the licensed market would have had $3.6 billion in sales, less than half of the $7.7 billion total sales in the state, meaning the black market would still have been larger than the legal market. üì∏: @wallyskalij

Southern Californians were treated to a spectacular wildflower bloom this spring, thanks to an unusually wet winter. But on Sunday, hundreds of visitors got to experience a rare and unique bloom at Cal State Long Beach. The blossoming of the Amorphophallus titanum, better known as the corpse flower, is an unpredictable phenomenon that usually occurs every five to 10 years. The flower‚Äôs bloom was originally expected to take place May 22 or 23, but instead waited until this past weekend to make its debut. üì∏: @jlcvisuals

Over the weekend, a small platoon of 14 Democratic presidential hopefuls descended on the California Democratic convention, held this year in San Francisco. Over 5,000 delegates and guests were in attendance, waiting in line to hear candidates speak about issues ranging from healthcare and abortion to labor policy and climate change. üì∏: @kentnish

Some migrants from Central America attempt to travel north by catching a ride on the roof of La Bestia ‚Äî  a notorious freight train that winds its way through Mexico toward the United States. Riding La Bestia is full of dangers: criminals that terrorize travelers, the risk of falling and losing an arm or leg, or worse. Police recently reported that several migrants were tossed from the train, with one dead and two with severed limbs. Despite the dangers, La Bestia has re-emerged as a preferred mode of travel for migrants as the Mexican government, under pressure from the Trump administration, has started making it more difficult for them to cross Mexico on their way to the U.S. üì∏: Liliana Nieto del Rio

At the New Arrivals Supper Club, monthly dinners aim to empower recently settled refugees by giving them opportunities to earn money, forge new communities and share their culture through food. Above, Naseema Kashefi, a refugee from Afghanistan, cooks at her Anaheim apartment for the "new arrival supper club" dinner. üì∏: @alschaben

Nearly six months after the Camp Fire killed 86 people and destroyed their town, the #Paradise High football team uses their sport as a unifying force. They lost so much, yet they still have each other, their coach, their schedule, and, above all, their mission. They all have different escape stories, they all have different tales of landing in trailers or hotels or on floors, but their mission is the same, one you can hear in spring shouts filled with equal parts joy and revenge. ‚ÄúThat fire picked a fight with the town of Paradise,‚Äô‚Äô says Greg Kiefer, the father of a player. ‚ÄúWhen these kids come back, they‚Äôre going to smoke people.‚Äô‚Äô üì∏: @wallyskalij

Four years ago, Julian Leyzaola was shot twice in the chest, once in the neck and once in the back in the Mexican border city of Juarez. It was the last bullet that left him paralyzed from the waist down. As a former soldier and police chief, Leyzaola had cultivated a reputation for exaggerated displays of toughness . At one crime scene he famously punched a corpse in the face. But after the shooting that left him paralyzed, Leyzaola decided that instead of leading a police force, he could lead a city. He‚Äôs now running for mayor in Tijuana. Analysts say Leyzaola has a good shot at winning. His candidacy has a hold on the one issue that dwarfs all others: how to calm the violence that has transformed Tijuana into one of the world‚Äôs deadliest cities. üì∏: @gcoronadophoto

Researchers have found high levels of radiation in giant clams near the Central Pacific site where the United States entombed waste from nuclear testing almost four decades ago, raising concerns the contamination is spreading from the dump site‚Äôs tainted groundwater into the ocean and the food chain. The findings from the Marshall Islands suggest that radiation is either leaking from the waste site ‚Äî which U.S. officials reject ‚Äî or that authorities did not adequately clean up radiation left behind from past weapons testing, as some in the Marshall Islands claim. üì∏: Carolyn Cole

Built by @disneystudios, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Small World‚Äù originally opened at the 1964 New York World‚Äôs Fair. After its successful run, the ride moved to @Disneyland. In the photo above, taken on May 30, 1966, #WaltDisney pours water from canteen into a channel through the "It's a Small World‚Äù attraction. üì∏: John Malmi

Nearly 30 years ago, in the predawn hours of June 4, 1989, the Chinese army was bringing a bloody end to seven weeks of student-led protests centered on Tiananmen Square, Beijing‚Äôs historic center. In this photo, former @latimes bureau chief David Holley, center with hand raised, interviews people in Tiananmen Square during the protests that led up to the massacre. Most Chinese today have little clear idea of what happened during the Tiananmen massacre. Many only know that there was an event called ‚ÄúJune 4‚Äù that no one is supposed to talk about. Still, Holley says, ‚Äú...these events will not remain hidden in China forever. Their memory, ineradicable, may yet profoundly shape China‚Äôs destiny.‚Äù üì∏: Courtesy of David Holley
Star Wars: #galaxysedge officially opens May 31. Here's a look around ahead of opening day. üì∏: @jlcvisuals @alschaben

Nispey Hussle had a plan to rebuild black neighborhoods in South L.A. and cities across the country, using a new provision in the federal tax code called opportunity zones. He had scheduled meetings to discuss his vision with lawmakers in Washington, D.C. But those meetings never happened. When #NipseyHussle was fatally shot outside his South L.A. clothing store, those plans were thrust into limbo. Now, Hussle‚Äôs business partners are forging ahead and are continuing the work ‚Äî the ‚Äúmarathon‚Äù ‚Äî he started. They launched an investment fund called ‚ÄúOur Opportunity,‚Äù that taps hometown heroes ‚Äî mostly wealthy black entertainers, celebrities and athletes ‚Äî to invest some of their money into neighborhoods in their cities using the opportunity zone tax incentive, leading the charge for economic development. üì∏: @luissinco

Cathrine Schmid longed to be a soldier. To wear the uniform her grandfather wore. She had a secret reason too: to belong somewhere that would suppress her innermost self. That was 14 years ago, when, as a man, she enlisted. Schmid wore the uniform and guarded her secret self at military bases in Missouri, Arizona, Germany, Kansas, Florida, Iraq, Washington and Korea. The Army didn‚Äôt change her, hard as it, and she, tried. Instead, in eventually becoming herself, Schmid took part in a still uncertain effort to change the Army. But now, the military that embraced Schmid has been directed once again to shun soldiers like her. üì∏: David Cloud

New "shooting insurance" ads across L.A. are part of a gun prevention campaign led by a student with help from the L.A. mayor's office. The ads, which are on bus shelters and social media, are designed to spur a wider discussion of gun violence beyond the shocked reactions in the aftermath of a mass shooting. ‚ÄúThis campaign can inform and engage folks about how to get connected and take action themselves, in a passive way like giving money or in a more active way ‚Äî getting out there, engaging, volunteering,‚Äù said Anne Tremblay, director of the gang reduction program, which is mostly publicly funded with a budget of about $30 million to $35 million. üì∏: @wallyskalij

You have 15 full weekends between now and Sept. 1 to get out of the house and enjoy the bounty of outdoor life offered by the beaches, waterways, hills, gardens and vibrant neighborhoods of Southern California. Visit the link in our bio for 15 ways to make the most of #summer 2019, including pop-up outdoor roller rinks. üì∑: @myung_chun

Memorial Day originated as #DecorationDay. Starting in 1868, Union Civil War veterans, organized into the Grand Army of the Republic, began Decoration Day to place flowers on the graves of Union soldiers. In this photo from May 23, 1987, cub Scouts rush to place additional flags for Memorial Day weekend at the Los Angeles National Cemetery in Westwood. Watch our Instagram story for more archival #MemorialDay photos. üì∑: Mel Melcon

The homeless often get blamed for the trash on skid row, but area merchants are also fouling their own nests, writes columnist Steve Lopez. The trash is a routine part of life in the downtown section of the nation‚Äôs second-largest city. ‚ÄúSkid row is the worst it‚Äôs been from a sanitation perspective and a safety perspective and a humanitarian perspective,‚Äù Estela Lopez, who runs the Downtown Industrial Business Improvement District said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy for me in the cheap seats to say what should or shouldn‚Äôt be done, but as a native Angeleno I feel that our city looks and feels mismanaged. When you take the oath to become mayor or a City Council member, your job is to run this city. It‚Äôs to manage this city.‚Äù üì∑: Mel Melcon

Los Angeles County is investigating whether an eviction notice sent to a 102-year-old woman at her longtime home in Ladera Heights violated temporary renter protections approved by lawmakers last year. Thelma Smith, 102, has rented in a small complex in an unincorporated area of Ladera Heights for nearly three decades. She received an eviction notice in March, telling her to move out of her Craftsman-style home by the end of June so the landlord‚Äôs daughter could move in. ‚ÄúIt is a reflection on all of us if we don‚Äôt do everything we can to bring this to a proper conclusion,‚Äù Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas, said in an interview Saturday. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do whatever we can to make sure that Ms. Smith is not unsettled, and that we protect the quality of her life ‚Äî a long life.‚Äù üì∑: Gary Coronado

Los Angeles County transportation officials approved the last major contract needed to build the Purple Line subway extension to the Westside, a significant step for the region‚Äôs most anticipated rail project in a generation. @metrolosangeles plans to open the Purple Line project in three phases: from the current terminus in Koreatown to La Cienega Boulevard in 2023; to Beverly Hills and Century City in 2025; and to Westwood and West L.A. in 2027. üì∏: @alseib

Compton rapper @YG was ready to drop a new album. Then his friend #NipseyHussle died. Despite YG identifying as a red-wearing Blood and Hussle as a Crip outfitted in blue, the two had been through a lot together. When Hussle earned a rap album Grammy nomination in 2018, YG said he couldn‚Äôt have been more ‚Äúgoddamned proud.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere ain‚Äôt really much to say. He wasn‚Äôt supposed to leave this soon,‚Äù YG said of Hussle. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been through stuff, trying to make it out of L.A. Being involved with the gang culture, you‚Äôre going to go through a whole lot.‚Äù With a tone of frustration, he added, ‚Äúand we made it out.‚Äù üì∏: @myung_chun

Violence has pushed more than 75,000 Tripoli residents to abandon their homes, with more than 500 killed and thousands wounded. The enemy, in the eyes of many in Tripoli, is renegade Libyan general Khalifa Haftar, who seeks to rule the country via his self-declared Libyan National Army. Here, a government of national accord fighter flashes a victory sign as he and his comrades go towards the frontline. For residents of Tripoli, this is the latest in a series of convulsions disrupting their lives since the 2011 uprisings that ousted dictator Moammar Kadafi. üì∏: @nabihbulos

Metro has spent more than $21 million since 2013 on efforts to beautify and restore 80-year-old Union Station. Improvements have included the installation of heat and air conditioning, as well as the cleaning of 268 leather chairs in the waiting area. Still underway are updates to the walkways and lighting, a redesign of the landscape to resemble the original plantings and the implementation of a system to accommodate the visually impaired. In 2018, Metro passenger numbers hit their lowest point in more than a decade as travel options, including Lyft and Uber, have become more readily available. Still, officials are convinced rail is going to be a much bigger part of Southern California‚Äôs transit future.
üì∏: 2,3 by @alseib, 1 courtesy USC / Corbis via Getty Images

At 97, Mo Kornfeld is the oldest active member of the 64,000-member U.S. Masters Swimming. In the water, her arms swing a bit stiffly. She doesn‚Äôt kick as consistently as her coaches tell her to. And her reach is restricted, as you would expect for someone who has logged nearly a century on land and water. She holds 16 age-group world records, 26 U.S. bests and dozens of national championship titles. ‚ÄúShe loves the feel of the water,‚Äù said Jim Montrella, who along with his wife, Bev, has become Kornfeld‚Äôs mentor and dear friend. ‚ÄúAnd she is ahead of almost everyone when it comes to attitude.‚Äù üì∏: @francineorr

Rainouts at Dodger Stadium are extremely rare. Since 1962, there have been only 17. A story in the April 13, 1976, Los Angeles Times reported, ‚ÄúThe rainout was the first for a regular season game at Dodger Stadium since April 21, 1967, when Don Drysdale was scheduled to face Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals. The Dodgers had played 724 consecutive home games since that date without losing one to the weather, and they had played 737 before the 1967 rainout, the first in the stadium‚Äôs history.‚Äù Since then, there have been some more: Between April 19 and April 21, 1988, the Dodgers suffered three consecutive rainouts. Following an April 17, 2000, rainout, the Dodgers entered the 2018 season with 1,471 consecutive games played without rainouts. üì∏: Joe Kennedy

Sirvan Moradi is one of just 103 Iranian refugees to arrive in the U.S. over the last seven months. Three times since 2017, Moradi‚Äôs family ‚Äî father, mother, brother, sister and aunt ‚Äî was issued plane tickets to the U.S. from their temporary home in Turkey. Three times the tickets were cancelled without explanation. Moradi‚Äôs father died last fall, after being told he could live the rest of his days in the U.S. Moradi knows this part of his journey should be the best one ‚Äî living in a suburban Seattle apartment, learning English, starting a new job and trying to make friends in a place that has embraced him. But mostly he feels anguish. Moradi‚Äôs case is an example of how changes to the immigration system have resulted in confusion and families being split apart. üì∏: @bvanderbrug

When Bruno Youn was 3 years old, his mother noticed something was off about her firstborn son. He could parrot what he heard. He could remember and recite poetry. But he could not string together words to communicate his own thoughts. She brought him in for testing and learned the truth: He had autism. ‚ÄúI could not cope with the idea,‚Äù said Josette Thompson, a Seal Beach physician. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt have a child with autism. Never talk. Never have a job. Never get married. You lose all those dreams for your child at once. I couldn‚Äôt go there.‚Äù She needn‚Äôt have worried. On Saturday, Youn, now 22 years old, walked across the stage to receive his diploma at Claremont McKenna College. But before he did, he stood before an audience of hundreds and did what his senior class elected him to do: deliver the student commencement remarks. üì∏: Gina Ferazzi

Look out for #Riverdale star #CharlesMelton on the big screen this weekend in "The Sun Is Also A Star." He told @amykinla that he feels the pressure of serving as a role model for young Asian Americans. ‚ÄúTo be in a movie dealing with romance, the implication is that you are deserved of love ... [As a kid,] I loved Ryan Reynolds or Ryan Gosling or Tom Hardy, and I thought, ‚ÄòOh, I can do that.‚Äô" üì∏: B√©atrice de G√©a for @latimes
Regram @latimes_entertainment

Lyft and Uber have tried to expand their fleets of drivers by recruiting workers with vehicles that wouldn‚Äôt pass company requirements ‚Äî and drivers who don‚Äôt have a car at all. But some drivers who rent through Lyft‚Äôs Express Drive program say it has made it difficult to get back on their feet. For Sinakhone Keodara, Lyft‚Äôs fees were hard to offset. He was paying close to $1,000 a month to rent the car and $60 a day for gas ‚Äî and he often had to sleep in the car. Until the weekly rental fee is paid, Lyft puts a hold on drivers‚Äô accounts, preventing them from withdrawing any income. Keodara said he at times had to overdraw his bank account to even fill his tank. üì∏: @genaro4707

This year marks the 80th anniversary of L.A.'s Union Station. Since 2013, Metro Rail has spent more than $21 million on efforts to beautify and restore the depot. But unlike in the nation‚Äôs capital ‚Äî and in cities such as Denver and New York ‚Äî the station has yet to become a central destination. Can Union Station reinvent itself as a community and transit hub in the heart of Los Angeles? üì∑: @alseib

Emma Taylor‚Äôs grit helped her get to where she is today ‚Äî finishing up her first year of teaching and preparing for graduate school at Loyola Marymount University. So did exhaustive evaluations throughout her years in school, which helped discern how her brain worked so she could figure out how to learn. So did accommodations, including extended time, in classrooms and testing centers like the one where she took the ACT. So did the hundreds of thousands of dollars her parents spent on therapists and tutors and private schools. The stories that emerged in the college admissions scandal are a reminder of the ego and arrogance sometimes associated with wealth and privilege. Taylor‚Äôs story is a reminder that an estimated 10% of the population has a learning disability and could legitimately benefit from extra help. üì∏: Mel Melcon

The Rochester family has spent the last 16 months on opposite sides of the U.S.-Mexico border due to President Trump's immigration policies. Unlike many in their predicament, Jason Rochester voted for Trump. As a white Trump voter, he makes an unlikely immigration activist. But having his wife, Cecilia, miss out on moments like walking Ashton to his first day of kindergarten has pushed him to try to persuade Congress to overhaul immigration laws. ‚ÄúWithout a law change,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúshe‚Äôs not going to come back.‚Äù üì∏: @alukastories

Caf√© Ohlone in Berkeley is a semi-permanent restaurant serving weekly lunches and teas and twice-a-month dinners of ancestral Ohlone cuisine. It‚Äôs the creation of two men from different Ohlone tribes, raised in different parts of California. Vincent Medina, left, 32, is Chochenyo Ohlone; he grew up in San Leandro and San Lorenzo. Louis Trevino, 27, is from San Pedro, but his heritage is Rumsen Ohlone, the people who inhabited Monterey and the Carmel Valley. Medina and Trevino are gay and coupled. LGBTQ people who come out publicly often find themselves alienated from families and rooted connections, yet Medina and Trevino, in reviving both food and language, are preserving the deepest parts of Ohlone culture. Medina says ostracizing people for whom they loved was a Spanish and American import. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs never been an issue with our people.‚Äù üì∏: Ricardo DeAratanha

Disneyland's Kim Irvine is arguably the person most responsible for maintaining the look and feel of @Disneyland. She. has led a team in #Anaheim responsible for maintaining the look, tone and feel of Disney‚Äôs original park, which at the end of this month will open what‚Äôs billed as the largest expansion in its history, a single 14-acre land dedicated solely to ‚ÄúStar Wars.‚Äù As #Disneyland readies itself for its future, Irvine stands as a connection to the park‚Äôs beginnings. Her mission: to ensure that the company doesn‚Äôt forget its past. üì∏: Mark Boster

This is George Ciampa, 93, who served in Europe with the U.S. Army during World War II. He was part of the D-day invasion and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Of the 16 million Americans who fought in WWII, less than half a million are alive today. Every day, about 348 die. As the their numbers vanish with time, their histories and stories are at risk of dying with them. Now, Ciampa is making a documentary to keep alive the events of a war whose horrors and heroics are remembered by a dwindling number of veterans. üì∏: @gcoronadophoto

City Beat, a new column from @LATimescitybeat, will tell intimate stories from all over L.A. about the central issues of life in the city. This week‚Äôs column explores loneliness. In L.A., people silently imploding from loneliness live among us. The People Walker wants to fix that.
A few years ago, Chuck McCarthy started a business fueled by the human need to connect. He kept seeing signs for personal training and dog walking, so he mashed them together: people walking. Some people might worry about safety while walking alone. Others might need motivation to get outside. But the central truth ‚Äî human loneliness. üì∏: Mel Melcon

On Sept. 10, 1976, Tropical Storm Kathleen came out of northern Baja California, Mexico, and pounded Southern California. It was the first tropical storm to arrive in Los Angeles since 1939. Los Angeles Times staff photographer Art Rogers found this youngster ‚Äúsurfing‚Äù through a flooded street. The image appeared on the front page of The Times the next morning.

The Times reported: ‚ÄúGerald was washed a quarter-mile down the channel, still astride his bicycle. County firemen threw the youth a rope, but he refused to abandon the bike. ‚ÄúFinally, firemen Michael L. Steele made his way through the water to the boy, tied a rope around him and, after ordering him to leave the bicycle, had him hauled ashore. ‚ÄúThe bicycle was swept downstream but Gerald was unhurt. Steele suffered skinned hands.‚Äù #TBT

Debra Stone is fighting the owners of her rent-stabilized Beverly Grove apartment building after what started as a leak in her kitchen morphed into more than a year of couch-surfing. Under a ‚Äútenant habitability plan‚Äù that the owner of her building submitted to the city, fixing the apartment was estimated to take a few months and be done by October. Instead, the process has dragged into this year. ‚ÄúI just want to go home,‚Äù she said. Tenants‚Äô advocates say Stone‚Äôs story represents a worrisome scenario for L.A. tenants, as the state‚Äôs housing crisis has sent prices skyward and tempted landlords to pressure longtime residents to move out so they can hike the rent. üì∏: @myung_chun

In a country with about as many people as Idaho, nearly every taxi driver in Northern Ireland has a story to share about someone who was involved in @gameofthrones in a pivotal way. Roughly 75% of ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù was filmed on soundstages and in otherworldly locations around Northern Ireland and the show has pumped more than $250 million into the local economy since 2009. Helen Sloan, who grew up in a small village in Northern Ireland and spent eight seasons as the show‚Äôs stills photographer, acknowledged what may be the greatest legacy of #GoT for those in Northern Ireland: hope. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve come so far as a people and now we have this jewel in the crown to be so proud of.‚Äù üì∏: @photomcq1

If you live in a single-family home in California, it‚Äôs likely everyone else in your neighborhood does too.That could change under a state measure that would require California cities and counties to permit duplexes, triplexes and fourplexes on much of the residential land now zoned for only single-family houses. The bill would not spell the end of single-family housing in the state. Developers could continue to build such homes on their land if they chose, and the legislation prohibits the demolition of single-family homes to build fourplexes without further government review. üì∏: Noah Berger

Jackie Goldberg has won the runoff election to fill the empty seat on the board of the LA Unified School District. The board seat has been vacant since July 2018 when member Ref Rodriguez pleaded guilty to campaign finance crimes and resigned. Goldberg was one of the top two finishers from the March primary, out of 10 candidates. A critic of charter schools, Goldberg ran with the backing of the L.A. teachers union, which asserted its power during a January strike to improve working conditions. üì∏: @robgauthier

Rural Spain has long captured the country‚Äôs imagination, portrayed in literature as otherworldly, sublime. But some villages are nothing more than a handful of stone houses along a dirt road. There are no schools, no hospitals, no bars, no children. Today, 90% of the population live in 1,500 cities and towns that together occupy only 30% of the country‚Äôs land. In many rural towns, aging male farmers are often the only ones left. This is where la caravana de mujeres ‚Äî a private bus that takes single women from Madrid to small, rural towns for an evening of food, drink and dance with local farmers ‚Äî comes in. In contrast to the rural towns, these women represent a cross section of Spain‚Äôs turn-of-the-21st-century immigration boom. They come for fresh air, kinship with one another and a chance at romance. üì∏: @angelnavarretec

Tim Conway, the comedian‚Äôs comedian best known for his work on ‚ÄúThe Carol Burnett Show,‚Äù died Tuesday morning in Los Angeles, his rep, Howard Bragman, confirmed to The Times. He was 85. Conway, who drew laughs from viewers with characters including the Oldest Man and Mr. Tudball, won Emmys for the series in 1973, 1977 and 1978. During his career, he won six Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe. The actor claimed he was born funny: ‚ÄúI am not really qualified to do anything but screw up,‚Äù he told The Times in 2013. üì∏: @jlcvisuals

Today there is about 4.5 million square feet of co-working space in L.A. About half of that belongs to WeWork, but new competitors are aggressively carving out niches of their own. Marisa Diaz and Daria Tsvenger work at a shared table at the newly opened Wing Los Angeles. The Wing is a co-working office set up specifically to support women. Co-working offices were once mostly shared by people who are self-employed, but their appeal is rapidly broadening to a wider swath of mainline companies looking for the flexibility to ramp up or wind down operations as quickly as situations demand. üì∏: @ccole_photo

Hundreds of residents packed a church hall a few weeks ago to hear community leaders rail against a new logistics center planned for the town‚Äôs airport. The $200-million air cargo facility could eventually generate some 3,800 jobs, garnering $6.5 million a year in revenue. But what kind of jobs, residents wanted to know ‚Äî low-paid part-time jobs with no benefits? And what about pollution? Community leaders argue that the new facilities should come with guarantees of well-paying, stable jobs and measures limiting air pollution. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

Doris Day, a leading box office star of the mid-20th century who achieved indelible fame in big-screen bedroom farces and put a sunny face on the working woman in postwar America, has died. She was 97. A former big-band singer and recording star who walked away from Hollywood in the early 1970s, Day had spent most of the last years in her beloved Carmel, where she was an outspoken animal rights activist.

From 1948 to 1968, Day appeared in 39 films, most often as the wholesome girl-next-door. When the light musicals she was originally known for began falling out of fashion in the late 1950s, she modernized herself by playing working women in romantic comedies. The transformation was box office gold. Day‚Äôs body of work shows ‚Äúhow much of an icon she was, how much she became in her own way, the female equivalent of John Wayne or Clint Eastwood,‚Äù Times film critic Kenneth Turan once wrote. üì∏: Bruce Cox

Comfort Town is a 115-acre housing development that has taken shape in a drab, Soviet-era district of Kiev, the capital of Ukraine. Comfort Town looms over the landscape like some giant Lego set in the brightest imaginable hues: screaming yellows, bright lime greens, blues and oranges and deep brick reds ‚Äî all rising into the sky. It began when a team of architects charged with building a housing development decided to make it to stand apart from the Soviet-era housing surrounding it. They wanted to build a place that might lift residents‚Äô spirits rather than crush them. üì∑: @alexeyfurman

Los Angeles has become a hotbed of Nashville hot chicken. In the last three years, more than two dozen #hotchicken restaurants, pop-ups and food trucks have opened in and around the city. But somehow, getting lost in the whirlwind success of hot chicken, is Kim Prince who runs @hotvillechicken, a hot chicken pop-up. She‚Äôs still struggling to get her hot chicken business off the ground, despite being the only one with any ties to the family that started it all, and one of the few African Americans making hot chicken in Los Angeles. She‚Äôs also the person making chicken that most resembles the stuff you‚Äôll actually find in Nashville. Follow @latimesfood for more food coverage, and visit the link in our bio to read more. üì∏: @mariahtauger

Just days before Uber began trading in one of the tech world‚Äôs most anticipated initial public offerings, Uber drivers in 10 U.S. cities, including Los Angeles, staged strikes over what they described as unfair pay and a lack of transparency. Drivers in Los Angeles participated in a 24-hour strike and picket line at Los Angeles International Airport. üì∏: @genaro4707

When ‚ÄúThe Rap of China‚Äù launched in 2017, it pushed underground Chinese rap music into the mainstream. Now, producers are turning to L.A. and other cities to find fresh talent. The show provides a large platform for rap artists to showcase their work but in return, artists have been careful about what they talk about in their lyrics. Contestants have been increasingly fearful of offending government censors in China. But some are willing to accept the content limitations. ‚ÄúIf you want to be in this show, you have to obey the rules,‚Äù contestant Xingyu Li explains. üì∏: @ccole_photo

More than 200 workers at Riot Games walked out of the video game developer‚Äôs Los Angeles headquarters to protest the company‚Äôs handling of two sexual discrimination lawsuits.
This action, the first of its kind in the video game industry, comes amid a surge in tech worker activism and a growing interest in unionization among game developers. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

On May 7, 1952, Los Angeles residents welcomed two dawns. The first occurred at 5:15 a.m. ‚Äî a flash from a Nevada nuclear device test. Forty-three minutes later, the real dawn arrived. This photo was taken from a balcony at the former Los Angeles Times building in downtown L.A. and published in the May 8, 1952 edition. The light ray from atop City Hall is from the Lindbergh Beacon. #tbt

Verlon Jose, vice chairman of the Tohono O'odham Nation, talks with visitors along the 75-mile border between the Tohono O'odham reservation and Mexico. In March, the Tohono O‚Äôodham tribal council unanimously approved 10 Border Control towers, with radar and night vision cameras capable of streaming footage to Border Patrol. Tribal leaders believe the towers could end up reducing Border Patrol‚Äôs presence on their land, but some younger members fear their elders have sacrificed their hard-won sovereignty. At this point, it remains unclear whether the Border Patrol towers will benefit the tribe, or lead to more enforcement. üì∏: @luissinco

Former Vice President @joebiden made his first visit to Los Angeles since joining the 2020 presidential race. He attended two high-dollar fundraisers and made a public appearance with Los Angeles Mayor @ericgarcetti. üì∏: @robgauthier

In 2017, Shamim Darchini had recently become a U.S. citizen, and she believed her husband‚Äôs visa application, which had been pending for two years, would soon be approved. The plan was for him to leave their native Iran and join her in California, where she was a college student. She knew that the Trump administration was trying to implement a travel ban that included Iran, but she was assured that close family members were exempt. More than a year and a half later, their application is still in ‚Äúadministrative processing.‚Äù That is all immigration officials will tell them. Discussions of Trump's travel ban tend to focus on the foreign nationals who have been denied entry. But thousands of U.S. citizens have also had their lives upended. üì∏: Ramin Mostaghim

On paper, it's known as Rainbow Canyon, thanks to walls bathed in shades of gray, orange and red. The Air Force refers to it as the ‚ÄúJedi Transition,‚Äù but almost everyone else refers to it as ‚ÄúStar Wars Canyon.‚Äù On the western edge of Death Valley National Park, the canyon, more than 5 miles long and up to 5,000 feet wide, is home to a fellowship of military veterans, aviation enthusiasts and photographers. They gather there for a glimpse of the all-metal birds that randomly streak across the sky ‚Äî and the Air Force and Navy pilots that maneuver them. üì∏: @pixtakerirfan

Cornelia Jeyi is shown on her way to the Freedom Day celebrations in Makhanda, the city South African President Cyril Ramaphosa, part of the ruling African National Congress, visited on Freedom Day. The municipality is one of South Africa's worst managed, and its decline mirrors the challenges facing South Africa‚Äôs young democracy. Many residents are direly poor, with garbage piling up, dirty drinking water and roads full of potholes. Millions of South Africans will vote in national elections on May 8, and in places like Makhanda, the ANC‚Äôs attempts to convince voters it is in the midst of a renewal may be too late, even for lifelong supporters. üì∏: @jamesoatway
Beginning this Wednesday, @lafoodbowl‚Äôs Night Market will take over @grandpark_la for five days w/ L.A.‚Äôs best food carts, vendors, trucks, pop-up dinners and drinks! More info at lafoodbowl.com

Mai Han is an outsider in Hong Kong, where many locals resent mainland Chinese. She and her daughter Alice live off Alice‚Äôs welfare because Han is ineligible for working rights. Divorced from her Hong Kong husband before getting residency, she‚Äôs waiting to get a one-way permit, which allows people from mainland China to move to Hong Kong through family reunion. In March, lawmaker Gary Fan proposed that Hong Kong cut the number of one-way permits in half and require applicants to show they can support themselves financially. Some mainland women, like Han, have protested, asking for an increase in the number of one-way permits so that they can work for their livelihoods and live permanently with their families in Hong Kong. üì∏: @suzanneleephoto

Rodeo Road became Obama Boulevard today in the heart of L.A'.s Baldwin Hills/Crenshaw neighborhood. For community members who have lived, organized and followed Obama‚Äôs career, the name change is both a tribute to the 44th president‚Äôs legacy and a reminder of what‚Äôs possible. üì∏: Carolyn Cole

Today horse racing fans flock to Churchill Downs for the 145th running of the #KentuckyDerby. But little attention is paid to the groundbreaking role of African Americans in the horse racing industry. Of the first 28 winning jockeys of the #Derby, 15 were black men. Some of these men are laid to rest at African Cemetery No. 2 in Lexington, Ky., located off a quiet two-lane road lined by towering oak trees. Leon Nichols, a Lexington native, works to preserve some of this history. #üèá üì∏: @robgauthier

Dozens of downtown residents went to Los Angeles City Hall to demand more foot patrols in their neighborhoods, saying they are frustrated by the number of assaults, open-air drug sales and incidents of harassment outside their homes. Several said downtown has become increasingly unsafe. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think downtown Los Angeles is getting less safe,‚Äù Police Chief Michel Moore told The Times. ‚ÄúI think that downtown Los Angeles, like much of the rest of the city, is in one of the safest times in its existence. However, there are still challenges ‚Ä¶ relative to homelessness, relative to street crime.‚Äù üì∏: David Zahniser

Join #latimes photographers tonight at 7:30 p.m. at @photoville as they discuss the challenges of covering the West Coast. The event is free and open to the public, and no RSVP is required. üì∏: @ginaferazzi

On September 24, 1932, Hollywood movie studios sponsored the Electrical Parade and Sports Pageant at the Memorial Coliseum. After several speeches, a slew of celebrities, a polo game and marching bands, the floats entered the Coliseum. The first was the ‚ÄúSpirit of Hollywood.‚Äù About 20 floats participated in the parade and guest of honor was presidential candidate Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York. #tbt

County officials say L.A. County is the nation's toughest to count because of its high concentrations of renters, homeless people and immigrant communities. Carolyn Cole took this photo community leaders from Mexico, Oaxaca, Guatemala, El Salvador as they plan for the L.A. census count. Catch Carolyn and other L.A. Times photographers at @photoville on Friday at 7:30 p.m. as they discuss the challenges of covering the West Coast on multiple fronts.

Tucked off a quiet two-lane road in Lexington, you‚Äôll find African Cemetery No. 2, the burial site of many of Kentucky‚Äôs first ‚Äî yet least remembered ‚Äî jockeys and horse trainers. Little attention is paid to the critical role black equestrians played in forming the horse racing industry. In the years after the Civil War, most horse trainers and grooms were black men ‚Äî so, too, were jockeys. Pictured is the headstone of Cassius Clay Tankersly, a young African American jockey who was killed while racing at Latonia in 1886. üì∏: @robgauthier

Clarisa and Zack Corber live in Topeka with their three children. Both parents, who are 33, dream of moving the family out of the cramped, 1,000-square-foot house they rent in a crime-plagued neighborhood. The Corbers, like millions of working Americans with job-based health insurance, are swamped by medical debt‚Äînearly $15,000 at this point‚Äîracked up despite the fact the family has been covered. In this special Times project, our reporter Noam Levey looks into skyrocketing health insurance deductibles and how they have transformed job-based health insurance over the last decade, forcing many to take on staggering bills and to cut back on essentials such as food and housing. üì∑: Nick Krug

Former First Lady @michelleobama took the stage at @ucla on Wednesday to urge students to reach higher by going to college, getting career training or joining the military. It was the first time she celebrated her initiative, College Signing Day, on the West Coast. üì∏: @alseib

Every Thursday in Long Beach, a group of transgender Latinas gather to swap gossip, confide secrets and talk about past traumas. The meetings provide a needed refuge ‚Äî a once-a-week respite from the stares of strangers and the heaviness of hyper-vigilance. We asked the women: What does this group mean to you and why is it important? Swipe left to see their answers. üì∏: Carolyn Cole

The world is in this bookstore‚Äôs rows, in poetry and prose, in the writings of James Boswell, in the celestial flare of sci-fi covers. David Benesty, the manager of Sam: Johnson‚Äôs Bookshop in Mar Vista, knows the bindings, spines and pages of them all. But things change. Buildings get sold. Rents rise. Benesty has been selling rare and used books here for decades, but the owner has put the building on the market and the shop is set to close by May's end. When a piece of a community succumbs to the weight of change, irreplaceable characters and singular moments that drifted through and defined the lives of countless Angelenos vanish against the desires and fascinations of new times. It is a curious and cruel evolution. The only thing sacred is change. This week‚Äôs Column One tells the story of the final change and chapter in the life of Sam: Johnson‚Äôs Bookshop. üì∏: @myung_chun

On the afternoon of April 29, 1992, a jury in Ventura County acquitted four LAPD officers of beating Rodney G. King. The incident, caught on amateur videotape, had sparked national debate about police brutality and racial injustice. The verdict stunned Los Angeles, and the riots that followed lasted for five days. More than 60 people lost their lives amid the looting and fires that ravaged the city. 25 years later, we take a look back at images from the Los Angeles riots. üì∑: Kirk McCoy, Gary Friedman, J. Albert Diaz, and Rosemary Kaul

The gymnastics season for UCLA ended a week ago, with a third-place finish at the NCAA championships in Fort Worth. It wasn‚Äôt the result the Bruins were hoping for as they sent coach Valorie Kondos Field into retirement, but it‚Äôs hard to think of the team‚Äôs season as anything but a success. Our photographer @WallySkalij spent hours following the UCLA women's gymnastics team as they rounded out their 2019 season.

Democratic presidential hopeful Beto O‚ÄôRourke came to Los Angeles Friday to kick off a days-long visit to California that will include a stop in San Francisco, multiple appearances in the Central Valley, and a town hall in San Diego on Tuesday morning. Speaking to hundreds of supporters hours after a shooter attacked a Jewish synagogue in Poway in suburban San Diego County, O‚ÄôRourke began his 20-minute speech by offering prayers for the victims and a vigorous call for gun control. üì∑: @wallyskalij

Yakutsk is remote, cold and isolated from just about everything else in Russia. It‚Äôs also becoming known for its underground punk bands. Several Yakutsk punk bands record under their own local label, Yunost Severa, or Youth of the North. In recent years, the bands have emerged with a fervor onto Russia‚Äôs underground music scene. Isolation and harsh climates, it turns out, are an inspiration for musicians. ‚ÄúIt makes you desperate,‚Äù singer Vlad Sleptsov said. ‚ÄúWe use that desperation in our songs about life here.‚Äù üì∏: @vasya_k

Tang Haiyan designed the Real Man Training Club ‚Äî which he says fluctuates between 2,000 and 3,000 members ‚Äî to get boys to face tough physical challenges ‚Äúin a manly way.‚Äù Shirtless runs, in freezing weather, are part of their activities. The debate over what is ‚Äúeffeminate‚Äù has become a popular pastime among older conservative residents of China, and mostly among men. The Real Man Training Club is part of a backlash against the makeup- and earring-wearing male TV, film and pop idols who have gained immense popularity in China. üì∏: @yancongphoto

Following a rain shower, L.A. Times staff photographer Jack Carrick took this image of Broadway in downtown Los Angeles on April 23, 1950. In the next morning's Los Angeles Times, the photo‚Äôs accompanying headline was ‚ÄúA Little Drizzle Puts a Quick Shine on Los Angeles' Broadway.‚Äù #TBT

Alejandra Campoverdi forged a path for herself that some only dream of. But something was looming that had the power to take all of that away. Breast cancer was attacking every woman in her life. But while others in her family ignored a lump, or let the doctors take the lead, @acampoverdi said she decided to become ‚Äúthe CEO of her own body‚Äù and planned a double mastectomy. Women who have their breasts removed never learn whether, in the end, it truly saved them. Then, Alejandra Campoverdi‚Äôs doctor called her with results. Visit the link in our bio to read more from Alejandra‚Äôs story. üì∏: @therealchristinahouse

The Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority has admitted it was responsible for the whitewashing of a historic Los Angeles mural nearly two weeks after the artist announced its erasure. Muralist Judy Baca, pictured, said she was devastated over the loss of her artwork, titled ‚ÄúHitting the Wall,‚Äù which was completed in 1984 to commemorate the first time women were allowed to run in an Olympic marathon. While Caltrans and @metrolosangeles have committed to helping Baca restore her mural, it‚Äôs unclear how much damage removing the gray paint could cause to the mural beneath it. üì∏:@luissinco

Evett‚Äôs Model Shop opened in 1948 in Santa Monica. It‚Äôs a classic neighborhood hobby and toy shop: small, a little dim and packed with things that are difficult to find elsewhere. But a steep rent increase has proven too much for owner Yvonne Evett, who plans to close the shop today. Loyal customers are mounting an online fundraising campaign to help the store reopen somewhere else. In this photo, the great grandson and grandson of the owner interact with a model plane. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

In 2016, Los Angeles voters approved a $1.2-billion bond measure to help fund housing for homeless people, with a goal of 10,000 new units in a decade. Now, after hustling to get as many housing projects started as soon as possible, city officials are coming to the end of the money available through Proposition HHH, and it‚Äôs not certain that promise will be kept. The city has committed two-thirds of the bond to secure a little more than half the units the measure was intended to subsidize. The new challenge will be figuring out how to stretch the remaining funds to make up the difference. To get close to the 10,000-unit goal, they will need to tap other sources of funding from the state and employ new ideas for building housing less expensively. üì∏: @alseib

Over the last six decades, more than 98% of Isle de Jean Charles has vanished into the Gulf of Mexico, leaving a frail strip of land just two miles long and a quarter-mile wide. As the state presses ahead with a $48-million plan to move the entire community out of harm‚Äôs way and build a new settlement, many residents say that holding on to their native land, or just keeping on with tradition, seems more important than building a new community. 69-year-old fisherman Edison Dardar says, ‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt planning to go nowhere, because I don't think the island‚Äôs going nowhere.‚Äù üì∏:Carolyn Cole

One hundred miles to the southeast, masses of festival heads were gathering in the desert for @coachella‚Äôs first April weekend. But this small crew of space scientists, synthetic biologists, investors, entrepreneurs and one partygoer with flamethrower had higher ambitions. By jet, bus and more than a few Teslas, they came to this desolate valley for #betaspace: a one-night, invite-only confab for the not-quite-yet-burgeoning space settlement industry. The goal? To spawn the companies and concepts that could allow humanity to establish bases on Mars (or maybe the moon), and to mark the first step on a new path for the L.A. tech scene. Its invitation promised Betaspace would be the place where ‚ÄúBurning Man and the Consumer Electronics Show collide.‚Äù üì∏:@kentnish

Bennett College, one of two all-women‚Äôs historically black colleges in the country, could be on the verge of closure. Years of financial woes have led recently to a federal court battle over its accreditation, without which the future of any college is dim. Pilar Hughes, pictured, plans to transfer from @bennett_college, as the struggles of the college became clear. ‚ÄúHaving a degree from an unaccredited ‚Äî or potentially unaccredited ‚Äî university makes no sense,‚Äù Hughes said. Bennett‚Äôs story reflects that of many of the nation‚Äôs 102 historically black colleges and universities, or HBCUs. In recent years, the institutions overall have seen enrollments plummet, endowments decrease and student bodies ‚Äî once entirely black ‚Äî become more mixed as HBCUs attempt to compete with schools that no longer shut out African Americans. üì∏: @veaseyconway

Yoshihiro Sako brews small-batch, artisanal sake at @densakebrewery in Oakland. Den, which is Japanese for ‚Äúrice paddy,‚Äù is what you might call a nano-brewery. @yoshihirosako released his first batch of sake in August 2018. Since then, he‚Äôs released about 1,500 500ml bottles every two months; his sixth batch will go out in the next few weeks. Swipe left to see photos of the brewery. üì∏: @colinprice

After years of being known as the best friend and sidekick to celebrities like Michelle Williams and Courteney Cox, Busy Philipps has come into her own as the host of the late-night talk show "Busy Tonight," which has quickly evolved into the best party in town. ‚ÄúI ‚Ä¶ know everyone,‚Äù @busyphilipps, 39, said before laughing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been here for a really long time. And I‚Äôve managed to carve out this super-weird career that spans 20 years, and in those 20 years, I‚Äôm a person that‚Äôs able to maintain relationships, both at work and in my personal life. You know, I‚Äôm like a gatherer. I‚Äôm a keeper.‚Äù üì∏: @jlcvisuals

In the shadows of Bangkok‚Äôs glinting high-rises, the plazas of sprawling shopping malls and the cozy courtyards of simpler neighborhoods sit countless tiny monuments to Thais‚Äô enduring belief in the supernatural. These miniature shrines, perched on pedestals and topped with sloping roofs, are known as spirit houses. Government buildings have them. So do five-star hotels, apartment buildings, offices, cafes and beauty parlors across Thailand‚Äôs frenetic capital city. Resembling elaborate dollhouses, they shelter the spirits that are thought to watch over that piece of land ‚Äî a deity, guardian of the soil or the ghosts of former inhabitants. üì∏: Shashank Bengali
Wondering what‚Äôs happening at the second weekend of @coachella? Here‚Äôs a look. üì∏: @kentnish

The L.A. City Council moved forward with a law that would bar landlords from refusing to consider tenants with Section 8 vouchers. Housing advocates say the law is needed because Section 8 bans are often used as a proxy to discriminate by race or class, and research has shown landlord acceptance rates are higher in places with the ordinances. ‚ÄúWe have a significant barrier to affordable housing in this city and that is the denial of people who have Section 8 vouchers,‚Äù Councilman Paul Krekorian, who proposed the legislation, told the council before the vote. Janet Knoy, 85, pictured, had to move from this apartment in Anaheim to Desert Hot Springs to find a landlord who would accept her Section 8 voucher. üì∏: Gary Coronado

The Stockton Economic Empowerment Demonstration is a pilot program to test a universal basic income. For the next year and a half, 130 residents of the struggling Central Valley city will get $500 every month, with no strings ‚Äî such as employment or sobriety requirements ‚Äî attached, in a social experiment that is as much public relations as rigorous research. What happens in Stockton is likely to inform the national political conversation in the years ahead. The pilot program also could create a road map for implementing future basic income policies in other cities or on a national scale. üì∏: @maxwhittaker

There is an evolution of the multibillion-dollar worldwide sneaker resale market, which is looking less like a hobby these days and more like an occupation. Most are small-time entrepreneurs hoping to earn some spending money on one or two pairs. But for others, it is a serious second-income business. The last study of the global reseller market estimated sales at $1 billion in 2016, a total that Matt Powell, vice president and senior industry advisor for the research firm NPD Group, said could be as high as $3 billion today but ‚Äúno one really knows.‚Äù üì∏:Ana Venegas

More than a dozen pastors presided over or aided with funerals and memorials for those slain at Columbine on April 20, 1999. Some have retired. A couple left the state. Others are pastors still. Like many who lived through it, they feel the tragedy regularly enough. Even though there were many pastors called upon for funerals of the slain, when they stood to deliver sermons ‚Äî trying to shepherd families through grief, a community through mourning and a nation through shock ‚Äî they stood alone. Visit the link in our bio to read their stories. üì∏:@mattstaver and @mpiscotty

Fragments of actual eavesdropped conversations around Los Angeles come courtesy of @overheardla, an Instagram feed that makes light of the city‚Äôs affectations by posting ‚Äúoverheard‚Äù submissions from ordinary Angelenos. The account, which has more than 1 million followers, has become a kind of shorthand to describe the comically absurd exchanges you can‚Äôt help but notice in trendy neighborhoods like Venice, Melrose and Silver Lake. Jesse Margolis, pictured, with his back to the camera, is an L.A. native and runs Overheard LA as a full-time business. He‚Äôs launched spinoff Overheard accounts including Overheard New York, Overheard San Francisco and Overheard London. The entire network has more than 3.3 million followers, according to the company. üì∑:Mel Melcon

After decades of working for others, Elizabeth Alcarraz decided to strike out on her own and open a sidewalk cart selling fruit ‚Äî and two years later she opened her shop across the street. The 56-year-old still likes to celebrate the freedom that comes with being your own boss. ‚ÄúThey won‚Äôt tell me ‚Äòyou can‚Äôt‚Äô or ‚Äòyou can.‚Äô I will do whatever I want in there and they will not say anything to me.‚ÄúI will dance there, I will spin around, and nobody will bother me.‚Äù üì∏: @dania_maxwell

At @sheroes_hangout in India, the entire cafe is staffed by survivors of acid attacks. There, survivors don‚Äôt cover their faces. They comfortably discuss the scariest moments of their lives and chat with customers from around the world. Under Indian law, perpetrators of acid attacks face a minimum of 10 years in prison. But many attackers aren‚Äôt caught, and women regularly see them, walking free. That makes the pride on display at Sheroes particularly powerful. Visit the link in our bio to see more. üì∏:Soumya Karlamangla

A new shelter has opened in Hollywood, sweeping 72 people off the aging entertainment district‚Äôs sidewalks. But the opening has triggered a crackdown on street camps that advocates warn is criminalizing homeless people. Social workers said having homeless residents under one roof at the shelter will make it easier to find housing for them. But some advocates worry that the accompanying crackdown in enforcement will drive people away from services. Hollywood‚Äôs homeless community is particularly vulnerable, with former foster children who aged out of the system, gay and transgender men and women, and older people with disabilities and mental and substance abuse disorders. üì∏: @gcoronadophoto

In 1928, Belle Martell and her husband, Art Martell, quit the vaudeville stage. They switched to boxing ‚Äî Art Martell was a former Australian lightweight champion ‚Äî and opened a boxing school near Reseda. Belle went onto a career as a boxing promoter, referee, announcer and trainer. In 2006, she was inducted posthumously into the California Boxing Hall of Fame.
In a May 21, 2006, Los Angeles Times article, Cecilia Rasmussen reported: "I don't know how it happened, but we overlooked this woman all these years," said former boxing promoter Don Fraser, chairman of the Hall of Fame's selection committee. In this photo from 1937, Boxer Jack Wofford takes a punch from trainer Belle Martell. #TBT
