Adam Driver, 35, is hard to pin down or pigeonhole. The former Marine and Juilliard graduate shifts easily, playing charming and selfish or quietly reserved or endearingly goofy or smug and temperamental. His latest starring role is in ‚ÄúBurn This,‚Äù which opened on Broadway on Tuesday night. Of performing on the stage, he said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what I enjoy most in the theater, when something happens and people aren‚Äôt sure how to read it. Some are reading it one way and others read it differently. The audience is at war with itself a little bit. That‚Äôs fun. There are a lot of moments like that in ‚ÄòBurn This,‚Äô which is a testament to Lanford‚Äôs writing.‚Äù üì∏: @alseib

A few months ago, Miriam Bautista worried she‚Äôd never get her daughter to eat healthy food. Noticeably overweight since about age 4, she‚Äôd devour salty snacks, fast food and candy. Her Mexican relatives proclaimed the tubbiness made her daughter even cuter. Bautista‚Äôs struggles with her daughter‚Äôs weight are hardly unique. Early childhood obesity is one of the most intractable health issues facing L.A. County, where about 20% of 3- and 4-year-olds are obese. Among school-age children, 45% are overweight or obese by the time they reach fifth grade ‚Äî higher than the percentage of Californians as a whole. The way Bautista sees it, change needs to start with parents taking childhood obesity seriously, educating themselves about nutrition, and controlling what their kids eat. üì∏:@dania_maxwell

To the horror of his parents, Ma Chao, an auto factory worker and a retired street cleaner from Jilin province in northeastern China, left school at the age of 14 to apprentice with a tattoo master. Tattoos were long largely spurned in China, perceived as associated with gangsters, prisoners and crime. Even now, it is rare to see tattoos in the street or public life. ‚ÄúPeople associate it with criminality. My parents were worried it was bad people‚Äôs business. They were worried I might get involved in gangs.‚Äù But, he insisted, it was like learning any other skill. Swipe left to see more photos of Ma and his studio. üì∏: @rrrobynnn and photo 3 courtesy of Ma Chao.

@laclippers announcer Ralph Lawler has long invoked ‚ÄúLawler‚Äôs Law‚Äù ‚Äî his belief that the first basketball team to score 100 points in a game wins. @ralph first made the decree in 1978 as the freshly hired broadcaster for the San Diego Clippers and has used it ever since. It has survived changes in the players, the rules and the way basketball is played. His folksy catchphrase is among the many found in local sportscasting. Swipe left to watch more about Lawler and his vernacular of Lawlerisms. üì∏:@robgauthier

The beaches by Hollister Ranch are pristine because of the ranch‚Äôs history of being so exclusive. But excluding the public goes against the idea that California‚Äôs beaches belong to everyone. Owners reached a controversial deal with the state Coastal Commission that essentially capped the number of people that could visit. Now the ranch is at the center of an epic beach access battle over whether the public can experience it. The stakes are high because the outcome lies at the heart of the question of access across all California beaches. But residents fear the loss of this treasured land ‚Äî and way of life ‚Äî that they‚Äôve fought for decades to protect.

Major Stewart lived in his Inglewood apartment for 23 years. Then his rent jumped to $1,725 from $855. Now, at 69, Major Stewart is moving into his family's home. A surge of economic development in Inglewood including the new $2.6 billion NFL stadium complex is wiping away its reputation as a battle zone for rival gangs and making rents and home prices soar. But that could displace many longtime residents including Major Stewart in one of L.A.'s last remaining African American enclaves. Watch our story for more. üì∏: @dania_maxwell

Each fall, millions of butterflies arrive in Mexico from Canada and the eastern U.S. But climate change is threatening to eradicate the forest that serves the butterflies refuge during the winter. Visit the link in our profile to read the full story. üì∏:@bvanderbrug

Climate change could cost the country dearly, according to an economic analysis of the effects on labor productivity, electricity demand and 20 other sectors in the U.S. No part of the country will be untouched, the EPA researchers warned. In California, residents have already become familiar with some of the climate impacts that will become more common in the state, such as wildfires and flooding. At the Capistrano Beach in Dana Point, pictured, Orange County public works crews use heavy machinery to remove a damaged boardwalk. Damage to coastal property is one of the greatest costs of climate change. üì∏:@alschaben

It‚Äôs springtime in Mexico City, and love is in the air. If there is a world capital of public displays of affection, it could be #MexicoCity in the spring, as the days start to lengthen and the jacarandas bloom. There, overcrowding, high rents and nosy relatives send lovers outdoors in search of a little privacy, making the leafy mountain capital seem like the most romantic place on Earth as couples canoodle seemingly everywhere. üì∏: @meghandhaliwal

As Trump made his way to California to visit a newly completed section of the border wall between Mexico and the United States, a group gathered in Calexico to protest President Trump‚Äôs threat to close the border. ‚ÄúWe are interconnected. We are one community. We are not separated,‚Äù said Jose Luis Olmedo of Comite Civico del Valle, an Imperial Valley civil rights group. üì∏:@dania_maxwell

In Inglewood, billions of dollars are being plowed into a new stadium for the Rams and Chargers, but athletic field conditions are bad and getting worse at Morningside High School just several hundred yards away. The fields have resulted in game cancellations, forcing the team to play many games on the road. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the responsibility of private pro sports teams to bail out struggling public school districts,‚Äù writes @latimes columnist Steve Lopez, ‚Äúbut there‚Äôs something obscene about a multibillion-dollar sports and entertainment colossus rising in a city of falling-apart schools, here in a state of remarkable wealth that has plummeted in national rankings of funding per student.‚Äù üì∏:@luissinco

President Trump embarked Friday on his third trip to California since entering the White House, a day after backing off his latest threat to seal off the border between Mexico and the United States. He arrived at the Los Angeles International Airport on Air Force One with Rep. Kevin McCarthy. üì∏: @kentnish

In an era when American cities are struggling with their homeless populations, a town in Arizona has embraced a 68-year-old homeless man who sports a long white beard and a Santa Claus hat. Santa James, as he‚Äôs come to be known, is treated like a long-lost friend. Santa James doesn‚Äôt like the terms ‚Äúhomeless‚Äù or ‚Äúliving on the streets.‚Äù He much prefers ‚Äúon the road.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt need a handout. He‚Äôs just a musician who wants to play the electronic keyboard that never leaves his side. Visit the link in our profile to read the full story. üì∏:@genaro4707

Last week, Hong Kong's government announced a plan to resolve its housing crisis by building an $80-billion artificial island. Critics say the problem is not land shortage, but housing policy that favors private developers over public need, driving up prices and making homes unaffordable. Pictured is public housing in Hong Kong built in the 1960s. üì∏:@suzanneleephoto

The rapper and community organizer #NipseyHussle left an indelible mark on the Crenshaw district of South Los Angeles, where he was raised. He celebrated that neighborhood, which is centered at the corner of Slauson Avenue and Crenshaw Boulevard, however he could. Watch our Instagram story for a look at some of the many locations along the street that influenced his music. üì∏:@luissinco

At least 250 were injured and 22 died in the past four years after Border Patrol pursuits along the American side of the border, a @latimes and @propublica investigation has found. Case after case shows Border Patrol agents using tactics that escalate the danger of chases.  Israel Caballero, 18, was one of three people killed during a car chase involving Border Patrol in November 2017. Border Patrol agents believed Caballero was driving suspiciously and ran a license plate check revealing the owner of the car he was driving was "armed and dangerous." Caballero crashed during the chase, and the crash killed him and two Mexican citizens in the car. Visit the link in our bio to read the full investigation. üì∏: Gary Coronado

In 1976, L.A. Times photographer Ken Lubas covered the construction of the Castaic Hydroelectric Power Plant. Inside one of the many pipes Lubas took this graphic silhouette image. A story in the March 21, 1976, Los Angeles Times reported, ‚ÄúSoaring superstructures of concrete and steel are transforming the barren shoreline of Castaic Lake forebay into a futuristic setting as crews speed construction of the Castaic Hydroelectric Power Plant toward 1978 completion.‚Äù Today the Castaic Power Plant has seven generators with a plant rating of 1,247,000 kilowatts. #tbt üì∏: Ken Lubas

Belly dancers from all over make the pilgrimage to Cairo for a custom costume made by Eman Zaki, the Coco Chanel of belly dance. If you need a tiger-print mesh ensemble with a diamante halter top encrusted with fake pearls, she can make it. Same goes for a gold and fuchsia-tinted stretch pleather mermaid gown with opalescent paillettes. Here, Eman is pictured with American belly dancer Alison Trow in her Cairo workshop. üì∏:@sima_diab

A familiar presence since her deceptively cheerful 2007 hit ‚ÄúLove Song‚Äù ‚Äî about how she‚Äôs ‚Äúnot gonna write you‚Äù one ‚Äú‚Äôcause you asked for it‚Äù ‚Äî Sara Bareilles set aside pop-star confession to give musical theater a go with the Broadway musical ‚ÄúWaitress,‚Äù for which she composed the score (and whose cast she joined for a spell in 2017). Her new album ‚ÄúAmidst the Chaos‚Äù marks @sarabareilles‚Äô return to autobiographical pop songwriting and reflects a shift in approach for an artist whose friendly early work demonstrated her reliance on gloss and economy. üì∏: @wallyskalij

For Charley Butler, a testicular cancer diagnosis in 2016 left him with thousands of dollars in medical bills after his insurer moved to cancel his coverage over a preexisting medical condition. He had to purchase a short-term health plan, which are often exempt from protections provided by the Affordable Care Act. Altogether, the bills would add up to more than $43,000. Short-term health plans, now increasingly protected under the Trump administration, may have more below the surface than meets the eye. Visit the link in our profile to read more. üì∏:@jimurquhartpics

A suspect in the killing of rapper Nipsey Hussle is in custody, authorities said, ending a two-day manhunt. Eric Holder, 29, was arrested in Bellflower on Tuesday afternoon. The arrest came after a woman who authorities allege was Holder‚Äôs getaway driver turned herself in. L.A. Police Chief Michael Moore said investigators believed the shooting was the result of a "personal matter between the two of them" but would not elaborate. Mourners visited a makeshift memorial for #NipseyHussle at his The Marathon store on Slauson Avenue Tuesday in L.A. üì∏:@pixtakerirfan

The few Californians who still make their living by harvesting mammal fur are given to brooding as animal protectionists and mainstream environmental groups place increasing pressure on authorities to outlaw the practice. As the support for trappers dies off, trappers who were taught the secrets of their trade before their teens by older friends and relatives are feeling isolated. Milton Brownell, pictured, an 80-year-old lifelong fur trapper from Fall River, Calif. realized that trapping was in trouble when, he said, ‚ÄúI ran out of world ‚Äî the places I used to trap were covered with new homes and tough laws.‚Äù üì∏: Roy Musitelli

California now has more than 1,300 charter schools ‚Äî more than any other state.  But the way the schools are overseen is flawed ‚Äî and questionable operators are making millions off the system. Visit the link in our profile to read more about the schools and some charter operators who have profited off the system. üì∏: Mel Melcon

Since @club_scum_ela‚Äôs inception in 2016, East L.A. residents Ray Sanchez and Rudy Bleu have made it their mission to provide a safe space for LGBTQ Latinx punks. ‚ÄúAs much as Scum is punk, it‚Äôs also very heavily Latinx,‚Äù Bleu added. ‚ÄúI just think it‚Äôs punk in ways that‚Äôs not traditional, and we push boundaries as far as performance and the music we play and the DJs we book.‚Äù üì∏: @francineorr

March 31 is Cesar Chavez's birthday and a holiday in California, Colorado and Texas. It is observed on Monday, April 1 this year and remembers a man who who organized the United Farm Workers union, staged a massive grape boycott in the late 1960s to dramatize the plight of America's poor farmhands, and later became a Gandhi-like leader to urban Mexican-Americans. The photo above was taken on Feb. 2, 1979 as #CesarChavez spoke to members of the United Farm Workers during a rally in the Imperial Valley as the workers were staging a lettuce growers strike. üì∏:Steve Fontanini

At the OB Bear restaurant in Los Angeles' Koreatown, the food is tasty, the regulars are close-knit, the Dodgers are beloved, and guests feel privileged. ‚ÄúI keep coming back because it‚Äôs one of my favorite places ‚Äî a seemingly anonymous space that actually has a very specific story if you care to learn it,‚Äù writes Times columnist @frankbear. üì∏:@kentnish

Grammy-nominated Rapper Nipsey Hussle was killed Sunday afternoon, shot in broad daylight outside his store in South L.A. in a burst of gunfire that left two other people wounded, police said. He was 33. #NipseyHussle was from South L.A. and was also a well-known community organizer who most recently was involved in the new Destination Crenshaw arts project. üì∏:@Genaro4707
Almost a month after Santa Anita stopped racing because of a surge in horse deaths, the track reopened under a cloudless sky and completed its eight-race card with no incidents. üì∏:@pixtakerirfan

Conservative media wunderkind Tomi Lahren has rebounded from her bitter split with The Blaze and now has her biggest platform to date as a host on @foxnews' new digital streaming platform. With a new platform, @tomilahren promises to be combative, unfiltered and happy to infuriate the opposition. She moved to L.A. a year and a half ago when she became a Fox News contributor, and she has stayed because she views California as fertile ground for Fox Nation coverage. ‚ÄúI love California. I think it needs to be saved,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThings that happen here trickle down. California is a cautionary tale for the rest of the country.‚Äù üì∏:@patrickfallon

Roughly 3 million people of Southwest Asian, Middle Eastern or North African descent live in the United States, according to a Los Angeles Times analysis of U.S. Census Bureau data. No county is home to more of these communities than Los Angeles, where more than 350,000 people can trace their roots to a region that stretches from Mauritania to the mountains of Afghanistan. In past census surveys, more than 80% in this group have called themselves white, The Times analysis found. But now, many feel that the census erases their identity like Sarah Shabbar, pictured above, who is of Jordanian heritage. ‚ÄúNone of these forms are allowing me to feel proud of it, because I‚Äôm just white according to them,‚Äù she said about the census. üì∏:@bvanderbrug

The United States is holding hundreds of asylum-seeking immigrants for days at a time in an outdoor pen under an El Paso bridge. Some migrants, including young children, have been held there for up to four days and have been forced to sleep on gravel. The hastily erected holding pen, U.S. immigration officials say, is an extreme but necessary response to a recent surge of Central American families that have crossed into the country illegally in recent months and asked for asylum. üì∏:@gcoronadophoto

The #Dodgers' bats came alive for #OpeningDay as the team hit a record eight home runs to power past the Arizona Diamondbacks 12-5 at Dodger Stadium. Hyun-Jin Ryu, who was captured here in a multiple exposure shot, surrendered one run to the Diamondbacks over six innings. üì∏:@robgauthier

San Francisco is on track to be the first city to eliminate new HIV infections ‚Äî or at least come close. The immediate goal of the city is to reduce new HIV diagnoses by 90% by 2020. San Francisco is only about halfway there but is moving faster than the nation as a whole and any other big city. Rand Hunt, pictured above is taking PrEP in his bedroom in Oakland. Hunt was born the year HIV was identified, and has lived his entire life in the shadow of the AIDS epidemic. üì∏: @wallyskalij

Enrique Aragon has spent three years and $45,000 to restore his 1966 Volkswagen 21-Window Deluxe Bus. It went from a shell with no wheels or seats to its current, showroom-readystate. ‚ÄúPeople point all the time,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúEveryone trips out because they don‚Äôt know they‚Äôre still around.‚Äù In fact, the Volkswagen Bus never went away, although at times it has fallen sharply out of fashion. And it‚Äôs back like never before. The current Bus-collecting frenzy is big in Southern California ‚Äî Orange County in particular ‚Äî where an alternative Bus universe first blossomed in the 1960s. The current Bus rush represents a new peak in an affair between Americans and the van that has existed for nearly 70 years. üì∏:@kentnish

As the #Dodgers prepare for Opening Day against the Arizona Diamondbacks, we look back at past Dodger spring training. The Dodgers trained in Vero Beach, Fla., from 1949 to 2008, when they moved spring training to Arizona. The facility became known as ‚ÄúDodgertown.‚Äù In the photo above, taken on March 8, 1959, Dodgers manager Walter Alson stands with his pitchers at Vero Beach, Fla. #tbt

In his 80s, Henry Tseng was doing yoga headstands. In his 90s, he was showing up for a 6:30 a.m. dance aerobics class. And in his 12th decade, he lifted himself out of his wheelchair and onto a recumbent exercise bike for a half-hour ride every afternoon. ‚ÄúThe older you are, the more you need exercise,‚Äù Tseng told The Times last year. He died Feb. 27 at 111 years and 231 days. At the time of his death, he is believed to be the oldest man in the United States. His true secret to longevity? Exercise regularly, smile every day, and choose not to worry, he said. üì∏: @mariaalejandra2.8

Many have stories of Vicks VapoRub from childhood, but among many Latinos the gooey salve is close to legendary. There are poems, essays, video spoofs, rap songs, scenes in Latino-themed TV shows ‚Äî tributes to what some consider the cure-all remedy. ‚ÄúIf I say to someone, ‚ÄòHey, bring me El Vah-po-ru!‚Äô they‚Äôll know exactly what I'm talking about,‚Äù said Luciano Roldan, 78, of El Sereno, who has been rubbing VapoRub all over, including up his nose, since he was a kid in the countryside of El Salvador. üì∏: Mel Melcon

Kale, strawberries and spinach top the Environmental Working Group‚Äôs list of the 12 non-organic fruits and vegetables with the most pesticide residue. The list, called the Dirty Dozen, is released each year by the nonprofit consumer advocacy group. According to the test data, more than 92% of kale samples contained residue from at least two or more pesticides. ‚ÄúWe were surprised kale had so many pesticides on it, but the test results were unequivocal,‚Äù said Alexis Temkin, the advocacy group‚Äôs toxicologist. @bigmac857 took this photo of the kale.

It's about to get harder to find a place to smoke or vape as L.A. County's supervisors updated the definition of "smoke" and "smoking" to include pot and e-cigarettes, and ban the public use of both, alongside tobacco, at beaches, parks, parking lots and golf courses and government buildings. @alseib took this photo of Marc Bury, who is visiting from Germany, vaping at the Venice Boardwalk.

Killing off rent-stabilized apartments to make way for tourist hotels? The struggle fueled by a housing crisis along the Venice boardwalk rages on as debate continues about Venice Suites, a 32-unit rent-stabilized apartment building along Ocean Front Walk that was converted into a hotel. Its owner, Carl Lambert, says he should be allowed to keep operating his business, despite proper permits and a violation of zoning laws. @bvanderbrug took this photo of Venice Suites. Visit the link in our profile to read more about Venice‚Äôs housing shortage and its battle to balance tourism and affordable housing.

Television stars of all stripes saluted the small screen at #Paleyfest in Hollywood including cast members from shows like @maiseltv, @nbcparksandrec and @thetwilightzone. Follow @latimes_entertainment for more and swipe left to see some of the stars, shot by @jlcvisuals.

Here, Kerlin Lopez, an asylum seeker from Honduras, waits with daughter Brikne, 3, at a bus depot. Lopez will await future court dates to find out whether he'll be permitted to stay in the U.S. after the Border Patrol released 250 migrants because there is no room to hold them. Normally, the agency would transfer the migrants to Immigration and Customs Enforcement to be ‚Äúprocessed," but officials said that a recent influx of Central American families has led to a severe shortage of space. @lorenelliottphoto took this shot in McAllen, Texas.

Senator @berniesanders gave a speech and joined University of California research and technical workers for a single-day strike to call for improved wages and protest outsourcing of jobs. Sanders formally announced in February that he is running for President in the 2020 campaign. @genaro4707 took this photo in Westwood.

A vivid super bloom has splashed the hillsides of Southern #California with color, thanks to a winter of record-setting rainfall. Those trying to get a glimpse of the wildflowers have led to traffic jams. And large crowds have left local officials to grapple with how to handle a never-ending stream of visitors. Don‚Äôt worry. There‚Äôs no need to rush. Luckily, wildflowers should continue to bloom over the next several weeks. @luissinco shot these photos of the bloom. Visit the link in our profile for the best places to experience the #SuperBloom.

Muslims and people of all faiths came together in prayer at the Islamic Center of Los Angeles one day after the shooting in a mosque in #Christchurch, New Zealand killed 49 people. Swipe left to see more photos, shot by Carolyn Cole.

Hundreds of students from across Los Angeles County joined a worldwide walkout Friday as part of a day of action to demand that more be done to combat #climatechange. The local protest, which began around noon outside City Hall, was part of an international youth movement calling for swift action to prevent or mitigate the devastating effects of human-caused #globalwarming. @katiefalkenberg shot this photo from the protest.

Legend has it that Platform Holly inspired Jim Morrison to write ‚ÄúThe Crystal Ship.‚Äù Nearly 50 years later, the future of the historic platform is in question. All drilling has ceased and the wells will be sealed. Swipe left to see photos from Platform Holly taken by @alseib and visit the link in our bio to see more.

The Sunken Place was just the beginning. In @usmovie, the monsters @jordanpeele wants his audience to confront are right there in the mirror ‚Äî glaring straight back. ‚ÄúI think [‚ÄòUs‚Äô] is more than a political movie,‚Äù said Jordan, ‚Äúbut in the post-Trump era, the finger-pointing in this country was turned up to a whole different notch ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs the finger-pointing at the outsider, the mysterious invader, or the finger-pointing at other Americans who voted a different way. I wanted to make a movie that allows everybody to face their demons, in whatever faction you want to put this movie through the prism of.‚Äù @yamphoto took this photo of "Us" writer-director Jordan Peele, left, with stars @lupitanyongo and @winstoncduke.

In Arizona, some ranchers voted for Trump and his promise to build a border wall and have Mexico pay for it. But the wall hasn‚Äôt been constructed and some vocal southern Arizona ranchers have lost faith in the Border Patrol‚Äôs barrier plans. Even if the barriers are built, many ranchers want the Border Patrol to change its policies and deploy agents closer to the new barriers. In response, some ranchers, fed up with the added costs of coping with Border Patrol and migrants on the border, have sold out to investors. Others, with ranchers that have been in the family for decades, refuse to sell. ‚ÄúThere is no compassion for those of us who live on the U.S. border in what they‚Äôre doing,‚Äù said John Ladd,  a rancher. @bvanderbrug took these photos. Watch our latest Instagram story for more.

There are all kinds of numbers you can use to describe the success of Hal Blaine, the wildly prolific session drummer that worked with Frank Sinatra and #Elvis who died Monday at age 90. According to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, which inducted him in 2000, Blaine played on 40 No. 1 singles. In 2015, Terry Gross estimated that Blaine had appeared on approximately 8,000 records.And Blaine himself told us in 2000 that over his career he‚Äôd collected no fewer than 263 gold or platinum plaques ‚Äî and ‚Äúmade literally a couple of million bucks.‚Äù But the most impressive of Blaine‚Äôs many numbers might be ‚Ä¶ six. That‚Äôs how many times Blaine‚Äôs playing helped a song win record of the year at the #Grammys between 1966 and 1971 ‚Äî a remarkable stretch that illustrates just how in demand the drummer was by pop‚Äôs elite in those days. Gina Ferazzi took this photo of Hal.

When @colesprouse left Hollywood at 18, he didn‚Äôt think he‚Äôd ever come back. The choice to work as a kid had not been his own: His single mother wanted to be around for the boys and have a steady career, and putting her twins in the entertainment industry seemed like a ‚Äúlucrative alternative,‚Äù he says now. But then Cole and his brother, Dylan, landed their own @disneychannel show, ‚ÄúThe Suite Life of Zack & Cody. They were full-blown teen heartthrobs. After graduating with honors from @nyuniversity, he‚Äôs starred as Jughead on the CW series @thecwriverdale and landed his first leading role in a movie, @fivefeetapartfilm. As for his future as an actor, Cole says he doesn‚Äôt expect to leave #Hollywood again any time soon. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to forget, because this industry has so many different sides to it, that the act of acting is an incredibly enjoyable thing,‚Äù he said. @myung_chun took this photo of Cole.

Months after California‚Äôs most devastating wildfire killed 85 people and leveled the town of Paradise, many former residents found the thought of returning unbearable. But others, whose homes escaped destruction, have come back to a life of surreal contrasts. Neighborhoods devoid of residents now bustle with the activity of workers felling blackened trees, hauling away debris and replacing downed power lines. John Cronister, pictured, is living in a trailer on his property on the edge of #Paradise. His home was burned to the ground along with five cars. ‚ÄúOnce I rebuild and sell this place, I‚Äôm out of here. I‚Äôm going to travel the world,‚Äù he said. Swipe left to see more photos of people affected including Steven and Yvette Roudybush, who have been told they have to get out of the rental home they have been living in and Charles Brooks, who also lost his home in the fires. Carolyn Cole took these photos. Visit the link in our profile to see more.

At least 115 firefighters and emergency medical workers took their own lives across the nation in 2017, more than the number who died in the line of duty, experts say. The rising toll of suicide has prompted concerns about an epidemic, as emergency workers face ever-lengthening fire seasons, more frequent mass casualty events and increased strain. In California, fire chiefs, labor leaders and counselors have committed new resources to support firefighters before they get to that point, including providing firefighters with informal, confidential, peer-to-peer counseling. @alschaben took this photo of Cal Fire Battalion Chief Ernie Marugg, left, as he hugs Will Mitchell, whose son Ryan Mitchell killed himself in November 2017 after working a shift at Cal Fire's San Diego unit. Visit the link in our profile for the full story.

Lashana Lynch has her own breakout turn as fighter pilot Maria Rambeau in #CaptainMarvel, the @marvel Cinematic Universe‚Äôs 21st release and first headlined by a standalone female superhero, played by Oscar winner @brielarson. @lashanalynch jumped at the chance to play Rambeau, an ambitious fighter pilot and mother to a young daughter, Monica. ‚ÄúYou just want to do a good job. I‚Äôm representing so many communities: women, black women, fighter pilots, the whole of the military and single mothers. So is that a big responsibility? Yes,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIs it something I was willing to take on? Absolutely.‚Äù Like @blackpanther, @captainmarvelofficial arrives at the perfect time when women are relearning their power on a collective scale. @myung_chun took this photo of Lynch in Beverly Hills.

As record rains have poured down on California‚Äôs coasts, dozens of sickened marine mammals have been turning up along the state‚Äôs shores this winter. Rescues of unhealthy seals and sea lions have nearly tripled for this time of year in Orange County, according to the Pacific Marine Mammal Center. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going through fish, funds and medical supplies faster than we expected,‚Äù said Krysta Higuchi, a spokeswoman for the Pacific Marine Mammal Center in Laguna Beach. ‚ÄúIt is a strain on all of us here.‚Äù The pups rescued have been dry, malnourished and emaciated, weighing half as much as they should, the marine center said. @alschaben took this photo of one of the sick elephant seal pups in a rehabilitation room at the Pacific Marine Mammal Center.

Last year, the Trump administration started preparations to build a border fence through a family cemetery just north of the Rio Grande. Homeland Security Department officials waived laws designed to protect sacred sites, flouting the age-old prohibition against disturbing the dead. The plan calls for the fence to be built along a levee that sits about a mile north of the meandering river that divides the U.S. and Mexico, cutting off parts of the cemeteries. The local Carrizo Comecrudo tribe drew volunteers from across the country to occupy the cemeteries, which they say sit on sacred native lands. While the Border Patrol says it has no intention of exhuming bodies and would ‚Äúpurposely avoid‚Äù the site, many remain critical. In the last major fence-building project by the Border Patrol in the Rio Grande Valley, at least one family cemetery was bulldozed to make way for a fence, a witness said. Carolyn Cole took this photo of protesters gathering in a prayer circle at a cemetery that could be affected by a border fence.

Much of Southern California has received above-average rainfall for this time of the year, and many areas have already recorded an average year‚Äôs worth of rain. Downtown #LosAngeles has received 17.98 inches since the water year began in October, surpassing the 14.93 inches the city gets on average annually. In addition, it‚Äôs been really cold. For the first time since forecasters began recording data ‚Äî at least 142 years ‚Äî the mercury did not reach 70 degrees in downtown Los Angeles for the entire month of February. Swipe left to see photos of rainy #LA from @luissinco and @pixtakerirfan. #‚òîÔ∏è

In Iraq, many risk their lives to find a hunted treasure: the desert truffle. And danger often follows in the search. In December, Iraqi guards at the Iraqi-Saudi border shot what they thought was a smuggler but was actually a truffle forager. Searchers are also aware of landmines and Islamic State. Truffle hunters travel through the desert hunting for clues: Cracks in the soil that indicate the truffle is near the surface and the presence of a certain type of grass. Once a truffle is found and dug up, it‚Äôs soaked in ice-cold water, scrubbed with a toothbrush and finally prepared for mealtime. @nabihbulos took this photo in Nuqrat al Salman, a southern Iraqi town that was the site of Saddam Hussein's most remote prison, where truffle merchants ply their trade in dedicated markets. Visit the link in our bio to read the full story.

Once best known for "Doctor Who," Matt Smith reinvented himself on @thecrownnetflix and is doing it again with a string of unexpected film roles, including Robert Mapplethorpe and Charles Manson. The actor, 36, typically plays edgy, live-wire characters, often drawn from real life. Ultimately, he sees his career as a marathon, not a sprint ‚Äî a logical conclusion for someone who has already gone from @bbcdoctorwho to Prince Philip to Charles Manson to the Spider-verse ‚Äî and he expects there are still decades to figure this all out. ‚ÄúHowever you get there, you get there,‚Äù Smith told @emilyzemler of his acting career. ‚ÄúAs long as you have a laugh and it‚Äôs good in the end ‚Äî it‚Äôs such a long period, your career.‚Äù @michaelnaglephoto took this photo of Smith.

The recent debate surrounding California‚Äôs transit future has reverberated statewide. But in the Central Valley, the upheaval ‚Äî like the bullet train itself ‚Äî is real. Houses have been boarded up, businesses moved, vineyards torn out, a highway realigned. The argument for a high-speed train crossing the state was that it would bridge #California‚Äôs inequalities. #CentralValley cities and towns have some of the most concentrated poverty in the state. The political vision was that it would connect them to the wealth and opportunities of the coast and bring higher paying jobs. Then, Gov. Gavin Newsom laid out plans to pull back on high-speed rail in the face of massive cost overruns. ‚ÄúYou see all the destruction?‚Äù Randy Van Eyk, a resident of the area told LA Times journalist Diana Marcum. ‚ÄúPeople lost their homes and businesses. And for what?‚Äù @zenshack took this photo of Lee Harris on a street in Fairmead, one of the towns that fought the prospect of high speed rail and then made peace with it.

Twice a week, animal-rights activists gather in Vernon, CA at the gates of the Farmer John processing plant. As an 18-wheeler approaches the farm, activists swarm the livestock trailer, pushing water bottles through the grates and offering calm words and love before the pigs arrive for slaughter. The demonstrations are organized by two nonprofit groups, the Animal Alliance Network and @laanimalsave, a group of @thesavemovement. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve never experienced love. ... That little bit of water we give them ‚Äî that‚Äôs probably the only love they‚Äôll ever experience,‚Äù said Ellen Dent, who heads some of the vigils on behalf of Animal Alliance. @robgauthier took these photos of the protesters and the pigs. Don Newcombe, the former Dodger great who was the first player in major
 league history to have won rookie-of-the-year, most-valuable-player and Cy Young awards, has died. He was 92.

He also compiled an impressive list of firsts:
He was the first outstanding African American pitcher in the major leagues and the first, in 1949, to start a World Series game.
He was the first black pitcher to win 20 games in a single season, 1951.
He was the first player, in 1956, to win both the National League most-valuable-player award and the major league Cy Young Award as outstanding pitcher.
At the end of his career, he was the first former major league player to sign a contract to play in Japan. üì∏: @luissinco

Meet Roxana Due√±as, the Boyle Heights teacher who's the face of the L.A. teachers‚Äô strike. 
The history and ethnic studies teacher is pictured head-on, her face framed by large glasses, her dark hair parted to one side. She looks confident, determined. She tells people to ‚ÄúStand with L.A. teachers.‚Äù The poster of Due√±as, 34, who teaches at the Math, Science, and Technology Magnet Academy at Roosevelt High School in Boyle Heights, is one of several commissioned by UTLA and done by local artists last month. With the strike entering its fourth day, Due√±as has embraced her role as one of its most visible symbols, while she joins her colleagues on the picket line. ‚ÄúWhen you see it you think, ‚ÄòWow, this is important work,‚Äô‚Äù she said of the poster. ‚ÄúA lot of teachers‚Äô work is done behind closed doors ‚Äî it‚Äôs not a public performance. It feels nice to be seen.‚Äù Due√±as spent less than an hour in Yerena‚Äôs studio, posing for portrait photos, some with a raised fist. He let her choose the winning photo and submitted the final work to UTLA for approval a couple days later. ‚ÄúI know how damaging education can be for young brown kids if it‚Äôs not used to empower us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRoxana is one of those teachers that teaches kids to become critical thinkers.‚Äù üì∏: @kentnish

L.A. teachers went on strike Monday for the first time in 30 years. LAUSD vowed to keep schools open, but it was unclear leading up to the week how many of the nearly 500,00 students attended. 
Ultimately, about two-thirds of students stayed away on the first day of strike. 
About 31,000 members of the teachers union had agreed to walk out to try to win smaller class sizes, more support staff at schools and better pay.

Thousands of picketing teachers and other union members ‚Äî many of whom had arrived at their schools before sunrise ‚Äî joined the mid-morning downtown rally in the chilly rain along with some students and parents. Police estimated the turnout at 20,000. The massive group then marched roughly a mile to school district headquarters on Beaudry Avenue.

Michael La Mont, 48, who teaches third grade at Hooper Elementary, said the march represented the unity of teachers working for better conditions. "We're marching for the future of public education," he said. "No one's doing this for fun. We're missing our kids. It's raining. We're not going to get paid.‚Äù üì∏: @yamphoto , @gcoronadophoto , @alseib , and @dania_maxwell

Big Bear Lake is home to a growing tourist economy and a small band of bald eagles. But for how long? 
The number of state-endangered bald eagles that migrate here each winter to roost and hunt has dropped at least 66% from an average of 25 three decades ago. Critics blame the decline on the increasing clatter of human activities at one of Southern California‚Äôs most heavily used lakes, which attracts about 7 million people.

Big Bear Valley‚Äôs bald eagle population has fallen to about eight today, U.S. Forest Service officials said. Yet they remain a draw for tourists, environmental activists and U.S. Forest Service officials, who regard them as local celebrities. üì∏: Courtesy of Friends of Big Bear Valley

Photographer @stuartpalley has devoted five years to capturing California blazes. His book, ‚ÄúTerra Flamma; Wildfires at Night‚Äù was supposed to launch last year but was held up because of the massive Thomas fire in Ventura and Santa Barbara counties. 
The book finally got published. But not before the raging Camp fire - the new record holder for California‚Äôs deadliest and most destructive - had broken out. 
If you momentarily set aside the human and ecological toll and focus on the aesthetics of the fire, a captivating beauty emerges ‚Äî by turns ethereal, haunting and almost supernatural. ‚ÄúFire has its own light source, which creates this eerie, warm, orange glow,‚Äù Palley said, adding that he prefers a Van Gogh-like night sky and its fleeting color palette.

A deported veteran has returned home. Fabian Rebolledo, an Army veteran, was deported to Mexico in 2010 and won a lengthy legal fight to return to the United States and have his lawful permanent resident status restored. 
Rebolledo was recruited into the military as a young man. He served at Ft. Bragg and in 1999 was deployed to Kosovo, where he was a peacekeeper who retrieved bodies of villagers killed by Serbian forces. Upon his return to California, his Kosovo experience began haunting him. He sought help for post-traumatic stress disorder and struggled with alcohol, leading to a series of DUI charges. ‚ÄúThat experience was harrowing for him,‚Äù said Lai, a co-director of the UC Irvine Immigrant Rights Clinic, which was able to reopen his case. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs all behind him now.‚Äù
The veteran still worked diligently to care for his family and obtained several jobs. But in 2007, a check he received from one employer turned out to be fraudulent ‚Äî that would be the offense that led to his deportation.

In Tijuana, Rebolledo slept on the streets and in shelters before finding more permanent housing with another deported veteran. He found support among a group of veterans who had also been deported, and he began doing advocacy work. He even helped create a mural at Tijuana‚Äôs Friendship Park to educate people about deported veterans.

Rebolledo crossed the border at San Ysidro back to the U.S. proudly wearing his Army uniform. üì∑: @kentnish

Can L.A.'s only LGBTQ-focused coffee shop survive? ‚ÄúIn so many ways, Cuties is absolutely the reason why I‚Äôve been able to survive in L.A.,‚Äù said Willow Fields, who moved here from Chicago three years ago.

This is what Cuties owners Virginia Bauman and Iris Bainum-Houle intended when they opened the business in July 2017. Both 34 and from Virginia, the pair wanted to create a casual hangout that‚Äôs welcoming to all members of the LGBTQ community, regardless of age or gender identity.
Such spaces are scarce.
Cuties has quickly become the daytime darling of L.A.‚Äôs queer social ecosystem. But despite a loyal customer base, Cuties ‚Äî the only LGBTQ-focused coffee shop in L.A. ‚Äî is fighting to stay open.
With its rainbow awning, doorway disco ball and hot pink-and-teal interior, Cuties signals that it is just such a place. The owners say they regularly receive emails from gender nonconforming customers who say that when they finally mustered enough courage to wear makeup or a dress, they chose to come to Cuties.
‚ÄúThere are people who come here presenting more authentically for the first time, every single day,‚Äù Bauman said.
It is this sense of purpose ‚Äî to help queer people feel less isolated in a sprawling city ‚Äî that makes Cuties unique. It also makes it expensive to run.
Bauman and Bainum-Houle launched a Patreon fundraiser to keep the business afloat amid a summertime slump. So far more than 400 people have committed to donating a combined $4,200 each month. That‚Äôs enough to keep Cuties open through September, said Bauman, who is a transgender woman. But the owners say they need to raise $12,000 a month to keep sponsoring events and paying their six employees. üì∑: Nick Agro for the Los Angeles Times

This is how a pre-med USC student came to sing ‚Äî and redefine ‚Äî a Coldplay song in ‚ÄúCrazy Rich Asians‚Äù

Katherine Ho received a text from a former voice teacher asking whether she‚Äôd ‚Äúbe down to submit a demo for an unnamed film and TV project,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHe was looking for a young girl who could sing Mandarin.‚Äù Ho grew up in a Mandarin-speaking household, and ‚ÄúYellow‚Äù was one of her favorite songs.
She got to work.

Despite the fact that she was starting her second semester as a freshman ‚Äî and was already overwhelmed with studies ‚Äî late one night, she got her dad on the phone to perfect the Mandarin lyrics for ‚ÄúYellow,‚Äù working line by line through meanings and inflections.
‚ÄúI actually fell asleep at the piano and woke up the next morning and recorded it before class,‚Äù Ho says.

A first-generation Chinese American from Woodland Hills, the 19-year-old is a lifelong singer who has performed on the NBC singing competition show ‚ÄúThe Voice.‚Äù She‚Äôs also minoring in songwriting at USC.
Ho auditions for a lot of stuff, so she filed the session in her memory bank and returned to her biology classes. When she found out she got the job, she still didn‚Äôt know how it would be used. She was told to show up at a Burbank studio, but it wasn‚Äôt until about an hour before the session that the studio team called to tell her the song was for ‚ÄúCrazy Rich Asians.‚Äù
Her reaction?
‚ÄúI freaked out in the car with my dad, who was there to help me with the dialect stuff,‚Äù Ho says. ‚ÄúAfter I found out it was going to be played at the very end of the film, it freaked me out even more.‚Äù üì∑: @wallyskalij

Elephants rarely get cancer, and scientists now think they know why. üêò  In what might seem a wild mash-up of the SyFi channel and National Geographic, new research has uncovered a surprising factor that protects elephants against the dread disease: a gene that had gone dormant in their mammalian ancestors, but got turned back on as their evolving bodies grew ever bigger.

Guatemalan asylum seeker Hermelindo Che Coc was reunited with his 6-year-old son at LAX.

Their reunification at Los Angeles International Airport later that evening would be among the first in California, as the Trump administration tries to meet a court deadline and reunite nearly 3,000 children it separated from their families in a zero-tolerance immigration policy. Many of the children and parents are Central American and are expected to eventually make their way to L.A.

For 25 days, Che Coc was detained without any news about his son. He was given a phone number to call, but the calls wouldn‚Äôt go through.

When he was released with an ankle monitor and finally spoke to his boy using a relative‚Äôs phone in Los Angeles, the conversation was unbearable.
‚ÄúPapa, I thought they killed you,‚Äù Jefferson told his father, crying. ‚ÄúYou separated from me. You don‚Äôt love me anymore?‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, my son,‚Äù Che Coc told him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm crying for you. I promise, soon you will be with me.‚Äù
Much of the ride home, he dozed in and out, his body jerking unexpectedly in his sleep every few minutes.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs wrong, mi ni√±o?‚Äù Che Coc said, rubbing his son‚Äôs forehead. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here. I‚Äôm here.‚Äù üì∑: @yamphoto

Under cover of darkness and all by himself, Magic Johnson arrived at LeBron James‚Äô Brentwood house at 9:01 p.m. on Saturday.

What's the magic behind six Kentucky Derby winners? üê¥ This horse caretaker from rural Mexico prepares horses for stardom. üêé 
It‚Äôs just before 5 a.m. and horses have begun peeking from their stalls. They‚Äôre waiting. He‚Äôs coming. ‚ÄúTime to wake up!‚Äù says Pascual Rivera. 
He‚Äôs been making these rounds in this barn nearly every morning for 14 years. They know him.

The story of the greatness of Pascual Rivera is actually not in the horses who are here, but the ones who are not. As horses go off to compete, Rivera always stays behind. ‚ÄúThey go,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI stay.‚Äù Rivera, 55, is grateful for the opportunity to continue a journey that began four decades ago on a farm in rural Mexico and continued on a winding path through restaurant kitchens and tack rooms and a hospital cancer ward.
It is a journey that every morning takes him home.
‚ÄúSometimes I wish I could be more part of all that big stuff,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut then I look around at these horses and I say, I am part of it.‚Äù Rivera has handled six Kentucky Derby winners in his 38-year career, yet his face is unknown, and, until now, his story has been untold. ‚ÄúSometimes, you know, horses are easier than humans,‚Äù he says. üì∑: @pixtakerirfan

Even if you don't know his name you know his work. Pop artist Robert Indiana, best known for his 1960s "LOVE" series, died on Saturday at his secluded island home off the Maine coast. 
But the man behind the art grew up in a household where the word "love" was never spoken, and he never found a lasting relationship, said Barbara Haskell, curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York. "The word was never used in his family growing up. He had a complicated relationship with the word," Haskell said.

In the end, Indiana found love through his art and adoration from the public. But real love, Indiana recognized, was a "dangerous commodity" that can die out and lead to disappointment, Haskell said. "On one hand he accepted that love became a symbol that brought him international renown," she said. "But for him love also has this element of fragility and precariousness.‚Äù üì∑: Matt Rourke/AP

NASA‚Äôs InSight blasted off from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to Mars. For decades, we‚Äôve sent spacraft to Mars to study the surface. This lander wants to look deep into its heart. 
InSight will deploy a heat flow probe to get a better sense of the planet's internal temperature, hammering it about 16 feet deep to avoid the influence of the day-night swings on the surface. The changes it detects should help scientists determine how hot Mars' interior is.

Artist David Hockney didn‚Äôt ask his subjects what they thought of the paintings. üé® He had them come in. They all sat in the same butter-yellow upholstered chair for two or three days. They took breaks every 45 minutes or so, and received a family-style hot lunch in the artist‚Äôs dining room. 
Hockney is 80 but says he feels 30 in the studio. 
There are portraits of his studio assistants, massage therapist, housekeeper, and cook. Others show Hockney‚Äôs siblings, the children and grandchildren of his friends. 
Most people die of boredom, Hockney says, but ‚ÄúI‚Äùm not bored yet. I‚Äôm still curious. I‚Äôm still excited by pictures.‚Äù The results can be seen at LACMA in what‚Äôs become ‚ÄúDavid Hockney: 82 Portraits and 1 Still-life.‚Äù üì∑: @luissinco

Five years ago, actor Diego Luna was living the Hollywood dream. A house by the beach, a production company with his best friend and a glut of good parts in great films.
But there was something missing from his life.

Mexico.

Why did he go back? "I felt an urgency to be a part of what was happening in my country," Luna said on a recent morning, sipping green tea at home in a quiet neighborhood on the south side of Mexico City. "I don't want my kids to see me looking at the news from my living room in L.A., complaining about what's happening in Mexico. I want them to see me here, fighting for something I love." üì∑: @wallyskalij

Alice Bag, the lifelong singer, writer, educator and LGBTQ activist, has been creating art since she was a teenage glam queen in 1973. 
It's actually incorrect, Bag stresses, to say she stepped away from the music scene.
"I don't feel like I took time off," says Bag, who also worked as an elementary school teacher for more than 20 years and has credited her role as an educator in providing clarity in her songs. "I've always made music. I wasn't always in the most popular bands. Some of us would play little coffeehouses and 20 people would show up." Bag has no regrets about not being in the limelight, even if during those wild years she confessed to chasing label deals alongside the Go-Gos and the Germs.
"People have asked me, 'Why do you feel you're not as successful as someone else?' I don't know, but it doesn't matter to me because I don't define success by how many records I sell or how much money I make," Bag says. "Success is doing the kind of music I want to do, and finding someone who connects to it. To me, that's the ultimate gift." On her new record, ‚ÄúBlueprint,‚Äù the original L.A. punk wants to correct the historical record. üì∑: Genaro Molina

Los Angeles is honoring ‚Äúbraceros‚Äù with a 19-foot monument. 
Decades ago, the U.S. welcomed more than 1 million Mexican nationals across the border. 
Through an agreement between the U.S. and Mexican governments, the temporary workers, known as braceros, came under a program to help fill labor shortages during and after World War II.

Almost 80 years after the Mexican guest worker program was implemented, and in the middle of a tense standoff between California and the Trump administration over illegal immigration, Los Angeles is honoring these workers with a statue that will be the centerpiece of a new plaza near Olvera Street. "It is great to see we're establishing not only the bracero statue, but also the plaza to recognize diversity, to respect diversity in a time that we're being attacked by our president," said Councilman Jose Huizar. "When our president calls many of these Mexican immigrants thieves, rapists, murderers and says they're not sending their best, let us remind him that many braceros came here and worked hard and built this country.‚Äù üì∑: @alseib

Of course officer Joe Cirrito was tired, but there was no turning back. "One foot in front of the other," he told himself as he dressed Saturday morning in full tactical gear and resumed his 100-mile run from an empty field south of Bakersfield to Los Angeles.

After some soup and oatmeal, he felt as though he had the downtown L.A. police memorial in his sights. Then he heard the news. 
For the sadness and grief, there was also anger, and with the anger came a surge of adrenaline.

As he ran, he learned of the death of one more. 
Another police officer, 30-year-old Greggory Casillas, had been killed hours earlier while chasing a suspect into an apartment building in Pomona. Casillas' partner was wounded as he tried to pull the rookie to safety. "All of us are a little crazy," he said in an interview before starting out, "but there is a bigger cause for this. It's bigger than me. It's bigger than the LAPD. We're talking about those who have given the ultimate sacrifice, and this is the least I can do. I can run.
"I can't sing, but I can run.‚Äù üì∑: @mariaalejandraphotography

Almost no one jumps on rainy days.

They jump when the sun returns and the masses step outside, reminding them of their misery. They jump during financial crises and in the early spring, when Japanese schools open and the pressures of life converge.

Yukio Shige's routine, though, is the same regardless of the weather.
Nearly every day, he clambers across the high basalt columns of the Tojinbo cliffs, the Sea of Japan thrashing 80 feet below. He peers into binoculars, seeking hunched figures on distant rocks, ready to talk them down.

In 15 years, he's walked 609 people back from the edge.

Japan's suicide rate is among the highest in the developed world. In 2016, there were 17.3 suicides for every 100,000 people, second only to South Korea among major industrialized nations. "The way I save people, it's like I'm seeing a friend," said Shige, 73, a retired policeman with a floppy fishing hat and a gentle demeanor. "It's not exciting or anything. I'm like, 'Hey, how are you doing?' These people are asking for help. They're just waiting for someone to speak with them." üì∑: Jonathan Kaiman

‚ÄúOh my God!‚Äù Astronaut Bill Anders had been peering out a side window, holding up a bulky Hasselblad camera to take photographs of the moon‚Äôs cratered surface. Looking up at the lunar horizon, he glimpsed something that no one had seen before: an Earthrise. üåè ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the Earth comin‚Äô up,‚Äù he said, a trace of wonder in his voice. ‚ÄúWow, is it pretty!‚Äù Down there, on that gorgeous blue orb, it had been a hell of a year. The Vietnam War was raging, and Americans were fighting one another in the streets of their own cities. Half the world was engulfed in protest; angry students nearly shut down France and were slaughtered in Mexico. The Cultural Revolution swept like a fury across China; the Soviet Union crushed the Prague Spring. Assassins claimed the lives of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy; a beleaguered President Lyndon Johnson declined to run for reelection. Now Richard Nixon was weeks away from inauguration.

It all looked so peaceful, from the moon. üì∑: Bill Anders / AP

If you thought praying mantises already look pretty cool, wait until you see them in these stunning shades. üòé  Scientists who put tiny 3-D glasses on these petite hunters have found that their stereoscopic vision system is unlike that of any other known animal.

And what they‚Äôre learning could prove useful in designing visual systems for future robots. 
Vertebrate animals use their stereoscopic vision to perceive depth. Each eye sees a slightly different image because of its slightly different vantage point, and the brain basically slides those two images together and calculates how far objects are based on the amount of sliding needed to match them up.

All kinds of animals, including humans and other primates, can do this, said senior author Jenny Read, a neuroscientist at Newcastle University in England. But the only known insect to also possess this ability is the praying mantis. üì∑: Mike Urwin / handout via Getty

An emergency town hall meeting after a fatal shooting by deputies of a 16-year-old boy ended in chaos. 
Deputies shot and killed Anthony Weber during a foot chase Sunday evening. They said they spotted a handgun tucked into his pants, but investigators never recovered a weapon.

Now Anthony Webrer‚Äôs family and residents are demanding answers from Los Angeles county sheriff‚Äôs officials. "Where's the gun?‚Äù John Weber, the teen‚Äôs father, asked. "I know where the bullets are, they're right in my baby's back." "You killed a 16-year-old!" another man screamed.

At one point, a sheriff‚Äôs captain was asked if his brother's family or community was "due something."
"Absolutely not," Capt. Christopher Bergner replied.
An angry group then convened around the panel, prompting authorities to end the meeting early. Bergner's response didn't sit well with those on the oversight panel.
In a statement Thursday morning, the Sheriff's Department said that Bergner couldn't hear the question being asked because of the noise in the room. He heard, "Don't you think we are doomed?" the department said.
"That is the only reason why he replied 'Absolutely not,'" according to the statement. üì∑: @kentnish

How long is your commute? Probably not as long as Carolyn Cherry‚Äôs. Her internal alarm clock wakes her up just before 3 a.m. She leaves her house an hour later to drive to the Metrolink station, where her train leaves at 4:43. It arrives at her stop at Union Station at 7:05. Then she gets on the Red Line and takes it to Civic Center Drive, where she gets out and makes it to her job as a clerical worker at the L.A. County auditor by 7:30. When her workday is over, she does it again in reverse, then gets 4 and a half hours of sleep before starting it all over again.

She‚Äôs been doing this for 16 years ‚Äî nine hours of work in between six hours of commuting. But it‚Äôs worth it, she says, because the rent on her two-bedroom, two-bathroom house with a yard in Hemet is only $800 a month. She helped put her kids through college and says she has no financial stress, despite her $400-a-month commuting costs. In Steve Lopez‚Äôs latest column, he looks at Carolyn and other workers who make long slog from the land of affordable living to L.A. on a daily basis. üì∑: @alschaben

The Sierra Nevada mountains grew nearly an inch taller during the recent drought and shrank by half an inch when water and snow returned to the area, according to new research from NASA‚Äôs Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

JPL research scientists think solid earth can store more water than what was previously thought. 
The role of mountains as storage in water systems has been ‚Äúwoefully underexplored in some respects,‚Äù said Jay Famiglietti, a senior water scientist at JPL and a co-author of the study.

Mountain water is a potential source of water that could be tapped to quench rising water demand. 
But mountain water is highly inaccessible, Famiglietti said. The next step is to find the pathways that mountain water takes. ‚ÄúIt's an important problem in mountain hydrology, but it‚Äôs especially important in regions like California that need to account for every drop,‚Äù Famiglietti said üíß

Why is the monstrous #ThomasFire so hard to control? First, the terrain is incredibly difficult. These mountains near Santa Barbara have steep canyons that are twisted and folded, making it hard for fire crews to take a stand. Cal Fire officials said they basically have no way to get crews on the ground to directly attack the western side of the fire. 
Second, the strong winds. Last week the area saw a record-breaking windy weather forecast ‚Äì it was so high the National Weather Service had to use the color code purple on their map, which they've never done before for Southern California. Some areas recorded gusts up to 80 mph. 
Then there's the fuel and dry air. Two months into the rainy season, #SoCal has yet to see rain. The lack of humidity is sucking the moisture out of shrubs and other vegetation, which is perfect fuel for flames. Many hillsides haven't seen a decent rainfall in eight months. ‚ÄúUnless you believe in miracles, I don‚Äôt see [the fire] slowing down until we get some moister air,‚Äù one battalion chief told us.

Southern California may get the Santa Ana winds every year, but ‚Äî according to recorded history ‚Äî they‚Äôve never been like this.

Why is Southern California burning in December?

The air is the driest it‚Äôs been here in recorded history, said UCLA climate scientist Daniel Swain. ‚ÄúThe [relative] humidities right now along the coast are much drier than what you‚Äôd normally see in the interior desert in the summertime,‚Äù Swain said. ‚ÄúOnce you get down to 1% or 2%, you‚Äôre down almost as low as is physically possible.‚Äù It‚Äôs just a pile-on of bad news for firefighters and residents on the edge of the urban-wildland interface who are the first to get hit by wind-driven brush fires. üì∑: @alseib

With a creak and a groan, the heavy steel gate on the fence between the U.S. and Mexico at Border Field State Park slowly swung open, allowing friends and family to reunite for a few moments.

For three minutes, each family hugged, cried, tousled hair of children or grandchildren some were seeing for the first time, then bid a tearful goodbye. 
And this time there was a first: a wedding. 
Brian Houston of San Diego, dressed in a light gray suit, embraced Evelia Reyes, who was in full bridal regalia of white dress with train and veil. They signed a few documents from the Tijuana municipal authorities, posed for pictures, embraced ‚Äî and became husband and wife.

Houston is a U.S. resident who said he could not go into Tijuana, but declined to elaborate. His new wife can‚Äôt enter the U.S. legally, so the two decided they would try to get married on this day when the gates opened. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a statement that love has no borders,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEven though we are divided by a giant fence here, we can still love each other on both sides of the fence.‚Äù üì∑: Howard Lipin / AP

Biologist Robert van de Hoek looks like a man bent on saving the environment. And when he‚Äôs crawling through a hole in the fence to sneak into the Ballona Wetlands, it‚Äôs clear he‚Äôs intent on doing it on his own terms. üåæüåø‚òòÔ∏è He has released parasitic native plants into the park in a personal strategy to battle flora he considers invasive. The 60-year-old has faced vandalism charges and a temporary ban from Ballona for taking shears to other plants he believed were crowding out rare native species. 
Now, he says he‚Äôs discovered a rare plant, this time in the heart of the wetlands where Ballona Creek meets the ocean south of Marina del Rey. And he hopes its presence will bring to a screeching halt a $185-million restoration project proposed by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife and supported by several leading environmental groups. Can a rare plant and a renegade environmental activist derail the Ballona Wetlands restoration? ‚ÄúThere it is,‚Äù says van de Hoek. ‚ÄúPalmer‚Äôs goldenbush,‚Äù he says with a proud smile.

16 years ago, Mexico began an ambitious campaign to fulfill its constitutional promise of ‚Äúdignified and decent‚Äù affordable housing for all. The government teamed up with private developers to launch the largest residential construction boom in Latin American history. Billions of dollars poured in from global investors, including the World Bank and Wall Street firms. But instead of elevated living standards, millions of families found themselves stuck in tiny, decaying houses with sinking streets, crumbling sidewalks and no running water. The complicated loans they took out only got more expensive, even if they made their payments on time. How did a $100-billion program to help the poor end up sending many of them into crushing debt?

Watch our Insta Story today to learn more ‚Äì or read the investigation at latimes.com/mexicohousing. (Lea la investigaci√≥n en espa√±ol: latimes.com/mexicocasas) üì∑: @bvanderbrug

This isn‚Äôt your typical Thanksgiving dinner. ü¶É

Pumpkin pie, cranberry salad and butternut squash were all laid out on the table. 
The guests of honor were a dozen gobbling turkeys, feasting to their heart‚Äôs content on all the fixings, cheered on by their human visitors from the sidelines.

The annual culinary celebration at the Farm Sanctuary in Acton puts turkeys at the head of the table, not on it. 
The life of a typical turkey in the days leading up to Thanksgiving is bleak, says Susie Coston, national shelter director at the farm. Male turkeys often are taken to melting farms, where their semen is melted out of the birds and hens are artificially inseminated in a separate facility.

Poults, or baby turkeys, are taken away in trays to be vaccinated, have their beaks trimmed and their toes clipped. They then are fattened up for three to six months and live in small facilities that prevent the turkeys from standing or even fully sleeping, Coston said.

The turkeys, now weighing more than 30 pounds, are then put in short crates stacked high on trucks and taken to slaughterhouses.

But a lucky few are spared. Farm Sanctuary rescues those turkeys that occasionally fall off the trucks during transport or obtains the birds from a multitude of other sources, including families that domesticate the animals but are unable to properly care for them. üì∑: @mariaalejandraphotography / @latimes

For decades, Southern California has waged a slow but successful war on smog. Angelenos have lifted the choking pall of air pollution that once shrouded L.A., bringing clearer skies and healthier lungs. But now, progress appears to be faltering. Smog has gotten worse for the second straight year, even though emissions are on the decline.

The South Coast Air Quality Management District believes the uptick is probably the result of more days with hotter temperatures and inversion layers, weather patterns that trap pollution near the ground.

Still, air quality officials are looking into other possibilities, including whether its emissions models showing a steady decline in smog-forming pollution from cars and trucks and other sources are somehow off.

Here is downtown L.A. Skyline covered in smog back in 1990. üì∑: Robert Durell

What‚Äôs an Arts District without the artists? üé®üé®üé® Named for the artists who made the neighborhood a creative hub in the 1970s and ‚Äô80s, the Arts District could soon find itself with few actual artists living within its borders.

City Councilman Jose Huizar, who represents the neighborhood, says an Arts District devoid of artists ‚Äúwould be a horrible irony and a cruel travesty for that community and for the City of Los Angeles.‚Äù Artists are an endangered species in the neighborhood they are most closely identified with.

But not all art is created equal. The presence of a big international gallery with access to capital ‚Äî such as the 116,000-square-foot Hauser & Wirth ‚Äî is different than that of individual artists, many of whom cobble a living out of poorly paid adjunct teaching positions. Plus, artists are frequently gentrified themselves, sometimes by developers who like to tout the power of art in their projects.

With rent hikes and evictions - is it the last stand for artists in the Arts District? 
Here, artist Sharon Ryan poses for a portrait with her cat in the Santa Fe Art Colony. üì∑: @yamphoto

L.A.‚Äôs palm trees are dying and it‚Äôs changing the city‚Äôs famous skyline. üå¥üå¥üå¥ Like so many things in Southern California, the palm tree was an import from somewhere else that over time became inextricably symbolic of its adopted home.

But the trees, so identified with the sun-splashed excitement of Los Angeles, are facing a decidedly darker fate. They are dying of fatal fungus and under threat of invasive insects in parks and along streets. And for the most part, the city has chosen to replace them not with new palms but with native trees that are more drought-tolerant and shadier, said Leon Borodinsky, a tree surgeon for the department of Recreation and Parks.

City officials say they don‚Äôt know how many palm trees have been lost. In 1990, a city tally put the number of palms on L.A.‚Äôs streets at 75,000. That number has declined, officials said, but they are not sure by how much.

This image from 2006 shows the sun setting on Melrose Avenue lined with Canary Island palms. üì∑: David McNew / Getty Images

At 100-years old, the Hooker telescope is still looking at the stars. ‚ú®  It was once the largest telescope in the world - a position it held for more than three decades. Its home, the dome at the Mt. Wilson Observatory, is historical.

Here in the San Gabriel Mountains, astronomer Edwin Hubble discovered that the universe existed far beyond the edges of the Milky Way galaxy. Later, with a former mule driver named Milton Humason, he discovered that the universe was not static, but was in fact expanding. ‚ÄúIn some ways, I consider Mt. Wilson Observatory to be the most important optical observatory in the history of astronomy,‚Äù said Alex Filippenko, a UC Berkeley astronomer. ‚ÄúIt was really an amazing instrument to use.‚Äù üì∑: @francineorr

How will the California fires impact wine? The wine industry contributes $57 billion to the state economy, by some estimates.

Unless you‚Äôre watching a treacly Keanu Reeves film from 1995, you probably won‚Äôt see a vineyard burn from end to end, vineyard managers said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very romantic, but it‚Äôs total fiction,‚Äù said Christian Palmaz, president of Palmaz Vineyards, where flames claimed one building but left the vines largely unscathed.

Fire officials said their crews often counted on the open space of vineyards to slow down the spread of the fire. Vines are still green, and there is little vegetation around them.

But the wine country fires could prove the experts wrong. Vineyards deep in wooded areas that burned intensely may have caught fire and others could have suffered heat damage at their edges.

Premium wine prices could go up, largely because people who like expensive wine don‚Äôt opt instead for cheap bottles ‚Äî they‚Äôll simply pay more for the fewer bottles of their favorite label.

UC economists think a $66 bottle could rise to $100 as a result.

Chances are, this is not your bottle of wine. üì∑: @bvanderbrug

The lives of the people in San Juan are now divided into two periods: before Hurricane Maria and after.

California's Mitchell Caverns are a natural wonder - and they're finally reopening this November after years of closure. The only limestone caves in the state park system are hidden in the Mojave Desert. Its glittering passages drew geology fans and outdoor enthusiasts, but the attraction was closed in 2010 after two rangers retired and weren't replaced due to budget cuts ‚Äì and then the vandals moved in. They ripped out copper wire, stole generators and signs and ransacked the visitor center. But now, after extensive renovations, the attraction is ready for the public again. (üì∑: Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

A 103-year-old Cambodian woman who survived famine, suffering and war in her native land beamed and waved a tiny #American flag on Tuesday as she became a #UnitedStates citizen. 
Hong Inh was the oldest of more than 10,000 people who took the #oathofallegiance in a cavernous room at the downtown Convention Center in #LosAngeles.

She came to the United States when she was about 97 years old to join a daughter and other relatives.

Three generations of her family, from her 80-year-old daughter Hieng Meng to 13-year-old great-granddaughter Melissa Tea, were there to see her . 
Her relatives helped Inh up from a wheelchair and she stood with a #flag in her raised hand to receive the oath. Her grandson spoke the words but she joined in the roar of applause at its conclusion.
‚ÄúShe says she's so excited and happy,‚Äù said her granddaughter Siv Taing, 40, of Orange.
Later, Inh stood again, with her hand over her heart, for the Pledge of Allegiance and a singer‚Äôs rendition of ‚ÄúThe Star-Spangled Banner.‚Äù Congratulations, Hong Inh!

He‚Äôs blind in one eye and deaf in one ear. But at 85, he‚Äôs not giving up on making music. üéº

Neither bills or advancing age can dim the glow of a drummer‚Äôs dream. It‚Äôs what gives him life. ‚ÄúWhen I was very  young I fell in love with jazz and that was all I wanted to do,‚Äù says Steve Hideg. ‚ÄúI was never interested in money, only interested in playing with American musicians.‚Äù ‚ÄúHello, my angel,‚Äù Hideg called out one day to a woman who knocked at his door and delivered a tray of food from St. Vincent Meals on Wheels.
Sometimes, that‚Äôs his only food in a day.

As one friend of his put it, in his mind, he‚Äôs a rich man.

Does he worry about anything? 
What if the rent goes up on his East Hollywood apartment? What if his good eye can‚Äôt be saved? What if he can‚Äôt drive much longer?
‚ÄúI live my life by three principles I learned as a Boy Scout. Faith, hope and love,‚Äù he said before reminding me he has everything he ever wanted.
‚ÄúAnd I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm still doing what I love.‚Äù
His struggle is real, said Hideg.
‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a beautiful struggle.‚Äù Check out the link in our bio for the full story. üì∑: @francineorr

He kept his promise, step by step.

The two-time Olympian fulfilled his vow, 15 months after suffering a spinal cord injury on a misjudged backflip that left him partially paralyzed, with no feeling in his hands or feet. Doctors didn't know if he'd walk again.

Nieto, 40, was determined to defy his doctors and make it all the way down the aisle. ‚ÄúIt's a monumental day so I think I need to do monumental things,‚Äù Nieto said before the ceremony ‚ÄúI'm definitely blessed and super happy to be here. I've worked really hard to get to this point and I think it's just the first step to many more in my recovery." üì∑: @robgauthier

Benjamin Ramirez gets emotional while talking to his sister in Mexico about the incident where his cart was overturned in Hollywood after a confrontation with another person. After approaching the vendor with a taser, demanding he move his cart, the man flipped it over, spilling the vendor's livelihood onto the street.
In the hierarchy of immigrant occupations, street vending is near the bottom. It‚Äôs a job from which you can‚Äôt be fired ‚Äî but it takes long hours every day to make a living. There are few symbols more potent of the slogging work than the pushcart ‚Äî which, balky as it can be, is a virtual livelihood on wheels. ‚ÄúYou have a vendor with his cart, and that‚Äôs his entire livelihood,‚Äù said Ulysses Sanchez, a Boyle Heights community organizer who is planning a happy-hour event to raise money for Ramirez. ‚ÄúYour actions have repercussions. You‚Äôre impacting someone‚Äôs ability to make a living and affecting their ability to get a piece of the American pie, the American dream.‚Äù üì∑: @francineorr

It hasn‚Äôt been the same for the Yurok people since the salmon dwindled. A rash of suicides pushed the tribe, California‚Äôs largest and one of its poortest, into an existential crisis. Local hikers knew him as Sam. He would encourage hikers he met on the trail to climb Mt. Baldy. He would hand out Clif bars, jelly beans, and Doritos. He would take selfies with other hikers. ‚ÄúIt got to the point where I said, ‚ÄòNo more pictures,‚Äô‚Äù said Ellen Coleman, 63, of Riverside, as she descended the ski hut trail. ‚ÄúHe calls me Superwoman, but he‚Äôs significantly older than me so I call him Superman. He‚Äôs incredible.‚Äù For Seuk Doo Kim, a 78-year-old South Korean hiker from Culver City, it was about the journey ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling God‚Äôs embrace ‚Äî this is better than church,‚Äù Kim said. His family didn‚Äôt understand why he wanted to climb Mt. Baldy every single day. He‚Äôs done it more than 700 times. He did it 100 days in a row at one point. Kim‚Äôs body was found near Mt. Baldy Tuesday. A sheriff‚Äôs helicopter airlifted Kim‚Äôs body off the mountain. His cause of death has not been determined.

Nithin Siddharth, a fellow hiker, posted a picture on Facebook that shows Kim with his friends at the summit, holding the South Korean flag.

The caption reads: ‚ÄúHere's to Kim and the power of the human spirit. For me he is literally the spirit of that mountain.‚Äù üì∑: @bvanderbrug

Congratulations to our photographer @KatieFalkenberg, a Pulitzer finalist for her photo series on Zika. 
Last year, northeast Brazil became the epicenter of the Zika epidemic, bringing enormous change to thousands of people‚Äôs lives. There was an unprecedented increase in cases of microcephaly, a condition in which babies are born with unusually small heads and often have associated brain damage.  Our in-depth series, Motherhood in the Time of Zika, brought attention to an under-reported side of the epidemic: the impact on rural communities in Brazil that are among the country‚Äôs poorest and most neglected. That struck a chord with readers, many of whom wrote to ask how they could help the families and the hospital that served them. 
Swipe left to see more of Katie's photos and follow the link in our bio to read the series.

At the end of the hearing, Super Court Judge Laura F. Priver smiled as she turned to the defendant‚Äôs table. You ready for the words, Mr. Wilson?‚Äù she asked. He nodded. ‚ÄúYou're discharged,‚Äù she told him. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù he said, softly. ‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù Today, Andrew Leander Wilson was set free. Immigrants too scared to stay in the U.S. are making the dangerous journey for protection in Canada. 
The tiny community of Emerson ‚Äî population less than 700 ‚Äî has seen its share of U.S. ‚Äúborder jumpers‚Äù over the years, but nothing like this. Until last year, residents might spot five or six strangers passing through town over the odd weekend, carrying backpacks and looking disheveled.

But since President Trump was elected last year on promises to crack down on illegal immigration and conduct ‚Äúextreme vetting‚Äù of Muslims, the numbers have surged. Recently, at least 22 people sneaked across the border near Emerson in a single night, including the man with the baby, who said he was from Djibouti.

The migrants are a small but rapidly growing population of asylum seekers who have lost hope that America will accept them and now must look elsewhere. Read the full story (Link in our bio) üì∑: @robgauthier
