For people dying on L.A. streets, he offers help, and he won‚Äôt take no for an answer. Anthony Ruffin goes into the darkest corners of the city and offers a helping hand to those suffering from mental and physical illness. His regulars include amputees and diabetics and drug addicts who can never get enough to kill the pain. Some are partially paralyzed and many are ghosts, their former selves barely visible in the shadows of unrelenting psychosis. But Ruffin keeps going back. His days start at around 3 a.m. If it‚Äôs cold or raining, he goes out earlier and searches longer. ‚ÄúHomelessness is a 24-hour business,‚Äù he says. His parents split when he was only 12 and had problems in school. ‚ÄúI knew I had to change my life and everything about myself,‚Äù he said, not wanting to disappoint his mother and stepfather. 
That began in earnest at age 32, when he went to vote. At the polling place, he bumped into a social worker who said she knew a man with the same last name as his. It turned out to be the father he had not seen in 20 years.

Ruffin learned that his father was homeless. 
Read Ruffin's story (Link in our bio) üóû üì∑: @francineorr

Meet #Moonlight‚Äôs Joi McMillon, the first black woman editor to receive an #Oscar nomination. As a junior in high school, she really wanted to be a journalist for the Orlando Sentinel. The news of former Cuban leader Fidel Castro's death at age 90 sparked cheers and celebrations in Florida early this morning. In Miami's Little Havana, people shouted, honked horns and beat on cowbells. One Spanish-language news site declared in bold type: "The Cuban Dictator Dies." Fidel Castro provoked Cold War confrontation and defied U.S. policy through 11 administrations. While the U.S. and Cuban exiles saw him as a dictator who trampled on the rights of his people, he was praised among many Latin Americans ‚Äúbecause he stood up to the United States ... and got away with it,‚Äù one veteran diplomat said. 
As President Obama said: ‚ÄúHistory will record and judge the enormous impact of this singular figure on the people and world around him.‚Äù (This is an undated photo of a young Fidel Castro. We received it in 1958.)

Every day in April, someone died somewhere in the world from a terror attack. We tracked every fatal terrorist attack throughout the month. April 19th stood out as the deadliest day. Terrorist attacks in five countries killed 71 people and wounded hundreds. One attack in Afghanistan that day was particularly bloody. A vehicle packed with explosives blew up near an Afghan intelligence agency, killing 64 and injuring nearly 350 people. Most were civilians, like the man and these children in this image.

Mildred was black, and her childhood sweetheart, Richard Loving, was white.¬†¬†And back then interracial marriage wasn‚Äôt just complicated ‚Äì it was illegal. Since they couldn‚Äôt get married in their home state of Virginia (or 24 other states), they went to D.C. and married on June 2, 1958. But back home, The Lovings were arrested for violating Virginia's 400-year-old anti-miscegenation laws, which nullified their marriage. With the help of the ACLU, they challenged that law and won ‚Äì earning a unanimous Supreme Court ruling that state bans on interracial marriage were unconstitutional. Today we celebrate their love story (and their anniversary).
So what does Loving look like for you in 2016?
Tell us how interracial marriage has affected you, post a photo and your story here on Instagram using #myLovingDay. We may select several submissions for publication on¬†LATimes.com¬†and in the paper.

RIP Antonin Scalia | 1936-2016

Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, the fiery conservative who used a sharp intellect, wit and a zeal for verbal combat to fight against the tide of modern liberalism, has died. He was 79.

Scalia was a dominant figure at the court from the day he arrived, and he could be an intimidating presence for lawyers who had to argue there. He had a deep effect on the law and legal thinking through his Supreme Court opinions and speeches. His sharply worded dissents and caustic attacks on liberal notions were quoted widely, and they had an influence on a generation of young conservatives.

His death set off a near-instant debate over how and when to select his replacement, and certainly altered the tenor of the 2016 presidential campaign.

More at the link in our bio. 
Photo: Sept. 26, 1986 Justice Antonin Scalia takes an oath swearing in to the high court. Scalia was the 103rd person to sit on the court. (AP Photo/Charles Tasnadi)

#SuperBloodMoon rises at nearly full eclipse over the Irvine, CA Spectrum Ferris Wheel this evening. üåíüåöüî¥ A lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth's shadow falls on the moon as it moves between the moon and the sun. The coppery reddish color of the lunar face has given rise to its description as a "blood moon." Because the moon will also be at its closet point to Earth it will appear about 13% larger than other full moons. The last time the two events coincided was 1982, and the next time will be 2033 üì∑: @donbartletti

The former offices of the #HeraldExaminer opened a century ago in #DTLA with red-tiled roofs and prominent arches in the Mission Revival style inspired by #California's past. The newest addition to #DTLA is the honey-combed exterior @TheBroadMuseum, a museum of modern and contemporary art at the corner of Grand and 2nd Street. The art will be culled from the private collection of founders Eli and Edythe Broad. Visitors can look forward to large pieces like the 82-foot long Takashi Murakami painting inspired by the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan, and "Under the Table," Robert Therrien's super-sized dining table set that dwarfs visitors. Today‚Äôs Great Read features Maj. David Brill flying a U-2, the iconic single-seat spy plane that is capable of flying to 70,000 feet -- more than 13 miles high. "There aren't a lot of people that get to experience that." The U.S. military is retiring its U-2 spy planes after more than 60 years in service ‚Äì in favor of surveillance drones. A big rig moves north along highway 160 on a levee along the Sacramento River.  The delta‚Äôs 11,000 miles of waterways and lush banks mask the #drought‚Äôs true effect on this part of #California. Reduced river flows mean that more saltwater is filtering in. State politicians are planning a tunnel system aimed at diverting more water from the area. And geologists have discovered that parts of the delta are sinking. Life here is changing.

What does four years of drought do to California?  We‚Äôre on a road trip to find out. Follow along with #drylandsCA or on our Tumblr: drylandsca.tumblr.com.

Trees in California's national forests are among the latest casualties of the drought. 
Just how bad is it? 12.5 million dead trees or 999,000 acres. ‚ÄúIt is almost certain that millions more trees will die over the course of the upcoming summer as the drought situation continues and becomes ever more long term,‚Äù said  U.S. Forest Service biologist Jeffrey Moore.

The last time California had such a die-off was during the great drought of the 1970s. An estimated 14 million trees or more died between 1975 and 1979. If the current conditions continue, the number of tree deaths could surpass that era, he said.

Read more: http://lat.ms/dying_trees üì∑: U.S. Forest Service

...And it's official; she's now in the running. It's 1957, and a line of kids ‚Äî the boys on bikes, the girls in bobby socks and saddle shoes ‚Äî stretches around a newly opened North Hollywood Dairy Queen. This was just one snapshot of a moment captured by photographers from the Valley Times, a mid-century newspaper that in small-town style managed to chronicle the birth of the San Fernando Valley and its postwar suburban boom. The Los Angeles Public Library is leading an effort to archive more than 45,000 of the defunct newspaper's photographs. So far, more than 11,000 images have been digitized and made public. For the full story, click the link in our bio. #library #northhollywood #thevalley #dairyqueen #vintage #archive #losangeles #tbt #throwbackthursday

Two blocks after Julie Hardin finished the Boston Marathon, the ground seemed to move. Smoke rose from near the finish line. Adrenaline surged through the 51-year-old Encino mother and washed away the fatigue. ‚ÄúThere were so many people and no way to get out,‚Äù she said. That never dimmed her resolve to return to Boston. Less than 24 hours after the bombing, she knew she had to run there again. Read the full story on Hardin and six other Los Angeles-area runners who are returning to Boston to finish something bigger than the race on latimes.com. After a two-year stay, Marilyn Monroe is saying farewell to Palm Springs. "Forever Marilyn," the three-story-tall sculpture will be dismantled this week so that the leggy tourist attraction can be shipped to its next location. But there is already talk of bringing the blond bombshell back to Palm Springs -- permanently. Some local leaders believe the artwork embodies the city's glamorous history, and they want to purchase it. Photo by Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times #art #marilynmonroe #palmsprings #california

In print today: @latimes reporter Alexandra Zavis and photojournalist @rickloomis traveled to the Central African Republic, which plunged into anarchy a year ago, to report on brutal sectarian violence that has led tens of thousands to flee. 
They followed this convoy of Muslims refugees on a harrowing journey to safety in Cameroon, one of a handful of neighboring countries that have taken them in.

Until 1974, this is how the Times was made. The Linotype machine, invented in the late 19th century, produced whole lines of type out of molten lead. Once cool, the lines were hand-set into steel frames to create pages. The paper once employed about 110 Linotypes on the third floor of the plant. Employees called "compositors" handled the machines and wore traditional green visors and often smoked cigars. This Linotype sits in the Times' Globe Lobby. #tbt #printjournalism #losangeles

From today‚Äôs Great Reads: Surrounded with her favorite color, Lilly Grossman, 16 relaxes in her room at home in La Jolla, CA, on Jan 6, 2014. She has written and published a novel "The Girl They Thought They Never Knew", based on her life-long disabilities. She has had a debilitating muscle illness since infancy and is plagued by nocturnal seizures. A genome scan revealed the answer to her condition, but not a solution to fix two mutated genes.
